reviewText: Compelling and complex miniseries about a mythical land and its various, competing kingdoms and characters. Based on the books which are even more detailed than the miniseries, which does a fair job of sorting the storyline out. Sex, violence, knights, beautiful women, love, battles, monsters, dragons, intrigue, everything one might want in a medieval saga. I usually do not like fake ancient kingdom films or stories, but this one is great, an exception. The acting is fine, the costumes beautiful, recreation of the kingdoms brilliant and the suspense thrilling. The viewer is left longing for more! We are caught up in the personal lives of the characters and care about them. But just as you are rooting for a particular favorite, he or she may be suddenly and violently eliminated. More twists and turns than one can imagine. Great fun and riveting action.

This series is for fear of repeating myself, awesome.
The casting director should be lauded, not since Lord of the Rings has anyone done such a spectacular job of selection. The story line stays close to the book with out been too slavish and the art direction, costumes and locales are faultless. Anyone who does not give this series a go is missing a treat.

I'm sure many fans of the TV series are tired of hearing the elitist opinions of those who have read the books. I'm fully aware of the type of person who falls in love with a book, or graphic novel, or video game, or whatever, and finds any adaptation that deviates in any way from the source material to be complete and utter crap. I want to begin this review by saying that I am not this type of person. The first two seasons of Game of Thrones I found to be utterly brilliant. Even the filler, or the areas in which the show deviated from the books was marvelous. The acting was superb, even the child actors for this show are in rare form compared to what you see in shows such as The Walking Dead. The first season blew everybody away, both long time fans of the book series, and those new to the world of Westeros. The second season cashed the check that the first season wrote, building upon the epic promise of the first season finale. Then came season three...

Before I get into the specific failings of the third season, I'm going to state for everybody the underlying cause of 90% of this season's problems. Greed. The studios trying to gouge more money out of the fans (and they have the balls to charge 40% more for the DVD/BR?!). The third book in the Song of Ice and Fire series, A Storm of Swords, has a lot happening in it. So using this excuse, the studio decided to divide the book into two seasons in order to show all the content. Since one thousand pages obviously does not fill 20 hours of television, they gave us lots of filler in order to fill time, like Margery and Sansa talking about boys. Furthermore, the actual content from the book moved at a snail's pace. Jon Snow took an entire episode just to climb the wall.

Now I would be able to forgive this, if it weren't for the fact that they actually cut out some of the important characters and things from the book. All the jokes about Podd's bedroom performance could maybe have been cut to actually give real screen time to Mance Rayder or Tormund? One of the most important plot points in the book is Jon's conflict between his oath to the Night's Watch and his sympathy for the Wildling cause. The show makes Mance Rayder seem like the typical generic tribal warlord, and Tormund is just some giant ginger whose name is only mentioned once. I want to see Mance playing the flute, and Tormund telling outrageous stories about his member. The only wildling that is portrayed as even remotely sympathetic is Ygritte. And even that seems less so after she shoots Jon half a dozen times with arrows. Not to mention we get to see barely anything of Barristan Selmy. And who is Strong Belwas again?

One of my biggest complaints here is also they they butchered (no pun intended) the Red Wedding. The most infamous scene in the entire series, and they messed it up. First of all, it would have been cinematic gold had they actually played the Reins of Castemere during the massacre, rather than playing the entire song, and then beginning the killings. Putting the right music to the right scene is something that you can only get in film or television, and it would have been something even the books couldn't show. Huge opportunity missed there. I also felt as though the gore and blood were unnecessarily cartoonish at some points. The throat slashing effects were straight out of Sweeney Todd, and the stomach stabbing scene felt unrealistic and awkward. Finally the scene were Robb actually gets stabbed. It would have been more dramatic to show Roose approaching him while he was on his knees, as it did in the books, then to just have him pop on screen and then off again like the 1990s animated Batman.

Now this isn't to say that the season didn't have its high points. The scene where Danaerys liberates Slaver's Bay and gains her unsullied army was one of the best in the entire show. In fact most of the Essos scenes were well done. Although I wouldn't mind seeing a bit more of Barristan Selmy. Also the scene where Jamie saves Brienne from the bear was fantastic. Ultimately though, the glowing parts of this season were bogged down by too much crap. The worst part is that they've painted themselves into a corner where season 4 is concerned, once again working only with half a book. Hopefully they will find a way to better manage their content.

In the past 2 seasons amazon released an instant video after the show aired on HBO. This year, however, they are not doing this. I'm assuming they will not be releasing any instant videos this year and just the DVD set at the end of season 3? Why are they doing this? Is it some contractual issue with HBO or something? I DO NOT WANT TO WAIT UNTIL JUNE TO WATCH THESE EPISODES!!! I started reading through the books for the second time (currently halfway through the third book) anticipating that I would be able to watch the episodes on Amazon Instant Video. So far they haven't released any episodes.... WHY!!

If this package is anything like the previous second and now re-released first complete seasons, it will be worth the price completely. I assuming this because it's been proven twice by now and also among other HBO releases. Therefore, what I expect or hope will be the return of the

5 blu-ray discs containing the ten episode season in 1080p picture and wonderful HD surround sound (with the fifth containing interesting special features, like season two's the animated history of Westeros),
two dual layer season DVD with all ten episode set,
and a digital season copy code where you can choose either redeem it with Amazon, UltraViolet, iTunes, or other instant streaming website.

My suggestion for anybody purchasing this through Amazon.com, please redeem at least one of you digital HD copies through Amazon.com. Not only is it more friendly than the likes of UV or iTunes, but YOU ACTUALLY GET TO DOWNLOAD A DIGITAL VERSION WHILE YOU HAVE A STREAMED COPY THAT IS PLAYABLE IN OTHER VIDEO PLAYBACK FORMATS. Sorry for the caps usage there, but there is no way to stress how more superior Amazon video is compared to the likes of iTunes's idiotic DRM usage where you have to only use a device that can use iTunes. Sorry, Apple, but if I own a "digital copy," I better fully own a digital copy of a TV season or movie. This is best way to own Game of Thrones!

Also, I would like to note that in the past, The price listed now will not be the actual price for this season set. I have purchased both seasons through Amazon.com for a discounted price knocking at least $20.00 off the original price (and yes for the Blu-ray/DVD/Digital set). If any of you are interested, please pre-order this either now and get it discounted, or wait till the season is fully announced on the website and pre-purchase it at a discounted price.

HBO has finished airing all ten episodes of this season and I'm sure that the show is renewed for at least 2 more. Especially since the source material for this season is literally half of the Storm of Swords novel, there is much to cover yet.  And wow! Just wow at the final two episodes of the season. The production company for this series is not afraid at all to show off what George Martin has in store for his characters. Major surprises and changes will occur that will surprise the unknowing viewer and also the devout A Song of Ice and Fire fan (also known as the, "they actually showed that!?" synopsis). Nit picky fans will point out what was changed be it dialogue or missing characters, but so far they seem minor but still entertaining to say the least. So far, Game of Thrones is still the best from book source to Live action TV fantasy series you will find.

I was hesitant about buying the latest series of Game of Thrones, but it was probably worth it.  Then they go and raise the price like 40% ?!?.  I will never again buy an HBO  series, DVD, or even watch it. Fire the one or two execs that made this irrevocably stupid decision to poison their followers. You will reap what you sow. I am also cancelling my HBO subscription on cable out of disgust. Some people need to retire early at HBO or whoever is responsible.

Game of thrones is awesome, you should all buy it.  That's the extent of my review.  Now I'm going to troll HBO and readers here with a sassy op-ed because I am tired of hbo's foolishness:

Dear HBO, you just don't get it.  People want to be able to buy a season and then watch them as they 'pop'.  If cable companies are strongarming you, pull a 'Prince' or rather 'the artist formerly known as Prince' but now again known as 'Prince'

Create a company 'nuHBO', then move all your content rights to it.  Offer this for free to all subscribers to HBO.  Buy more channels if you have to.

Then, fill HBO with static 24x7, after cable companies dump you for having no content anymore, for being recalcitrant and obnoxious and difficult, then switch back to HBO or even 'HBO Classic' and then make all your video content available on Amazon, Google Play and Apple.

It's 2013 guys.  Article published saying Netflix streaming has surpassed tv watching.  Consumers are waiting in line with money in hand to give to you.  All my friends have ditched cable and use Netflix + Amazon + Hulu set top boxes.  GET WITH IT.  Cable is dead.

Comcast will live on because they own Paramount and NBC, but otherwise, their main thing is dead.

Want to ride that horse over a cliff?  Or join our picnic here, in Amazon instant video world.

I am not a reader of fantasy, but I must confess these 5-books written by George R.R. Martin are the best books I have ever read in a very very long time. I have been following the series on HBO for the last three years. If you haven't read the books I recommend it because there is so much more in the books that it is nearly impossible for the producers and directors to put on screen. Parents a word of caution, the content of this series is not for children. This has adult content, material, and scenes that may not be suitable for young children. The screen version of the books is so very close to the storyline. It is incredibly exciting and well done, the actors and actresses are superb. The locations inwhich the movie was filmed is also incredible. Seasons 1 and 2 are apart of my video libary and I have already pre-ordered season 3. I am hooked and you will be to. If you don't have HBO on your cable line-up, buy the DVDs you won't regret it. Buy it now!

Game Of Thrones Season 3 Blu-Ray available February 18th, 2014

I am a huge fan of the books and the show. I have Inside HBO's Game Of Thrones: Collector's Edition book, A Feast of Ice and Fire Cookbook, and even pre-ordered The World of Ice and Fire: The Official History of Westeros and The World of A Game of Thrones. I play the Game of Thrones board game almost every Saturday with my friends. I even have the comic book and have coasters and a Targaryen t-shirt. I also have the first two seasons on Blu-Ray (pre-ordered them here like 6 months in advance). I am a huge fan of the series.

A Game of Thrones (book 1 in the Song of Ice and Fire book series) covered the first season. A Clash of Kings (book 2) was told in the second season. A Storm of Swords (book 3) however, is so meaty that D.B. Weiss and David Benioff want to cut out nothing of importance so it will span this season (season 3) and the next season (season 4). So for those who haven't watched this season yet, minor *spoilers* ahead. I won't give away anything too important and will keep these episode reviews mainly as a synopsis, and I won't complain about what's different from the book to screen adaptation, I promise.

This show has it all, mystery, drama, action, sex and nudity, monsters, magic and political intrigue. It's shot all over the world (Northern Ireland, Malta, Croatia, and Iceland) and the sets and costume design are amazing. Music by Ramin Djawadi is brooding, heavy, sad and exciting. This show is adult in nature and content, but speaks to the kid in me who dreams of sword fighting, joining battles and fighting for freedom, battling monsters and seeing Dragons and exotic women. This show is easily one of the best shows ever created. It's up there with The Wire, Breaking Bad, Lost, Shameless, Deadwood, Doctor Who, The Walking Dead and Justified. Shows that are pure escapism and a bit fantasy that are grounded in reality of the Human condition and that people can relate to. Granted I don't think any of us can relate to seeing sword fights and White Walkers or Dragons flying around, yet we can all relate to losing loved ones, being betrayed, and standing up for what is right and just. This show is an epic masterpiece, a classic that is sure to be talked about for years to come. FULLY APPROVED.

If I had written this review years ago I wouldve given the product a three star review. Game of Thrones is a five star series, but I hated the packages the DVDs came in. Each year Ive bought the DVDs as soon as they are available and hated the packages, wishing HBO would put the DVDs in some decent plastic snap cases. After buying seven seasons of the folding cardboard contraptions Ive learned to live with them. Now I see season one DVDs in plastic snap cases being sold at Walmart! Frickin HBO.

Game of Thrones has been my favorite show since it started, which was a big surprise to me. I remember watching the ads for it back when The Walking Dead was my favorite show, which it won by default after Battlestar Galatica ended. The Game of Thrones ads looked boring to me. I thought the show was going to be another mediocre costume drama. Boy was I wrong.

Ive read the six Game of Thrones books between seasons and I re-watch every episode of every season starting with episode one each year before the next season begins.

If you're looking for good stuff to watch consider miniseries like The Astronauts Wives Club (2015), Band of Brothers (2001), Frank Herberts Dune (2000), Frank Herberts Children of Dune (2003), Into the West (2005), Lonesome Dove (1989), Manhattan (2014-2015), Return to Lonesome Dove (1993), Pride and Prejudice (1995), Taken (2002) and The 10th Kingdom (2000), which are all terrific because they have clear beginnings that establish an objective, then strong middles and conclusive endings where the goal is achieved, like a good novel.

Other shows Ive really enjoyed include Battlestar Galactica (2004-2009), Breaking Bad (2008-2013), Cowboy Bebop (1998), Downton Abbey (2010-2015), Firefly (2002), Granite Flats (2013-2015), The IT Crowd (2006-2013), Jericho (2006-2008), Merlin (2008-2012), The Prisoner (1967-1968), Rome (2005-2007), Spartacus: Gods of the Arena (2011), Spartacus: Blood and Sand (2010), Stargate: SG-1 (1997-2007), Stargate: Atlantis (2004-2009), Star Trek (1966-1969), Star Trek Voyager (1995-2001), and The Tudors (2007-2010). I didn't list any contemporary series Im following that don't have an end date yet, not conducive to binge watching from beginning to finish.

If you like reading try some of my favorite fantasy and sci-fi authors: Richard Adams, Palo Bacigulupi, Suzanne Collins, Abe Evergreen, Diana Gabaldon, Hugh Howey, George Martin, Brandon Sanderson, John Scalzi, and Andy Weir.

One of the greatest series ever made.

As with every season of GoT you are going to get a wide variety of combat, (and the gore that goes along with it), language, nudity, sex, adult situations and complicated story lines so this series is not for children.

Pros the same as previous seasons: Excellent acting, story lines, costumes, sets, etc. Many new characters and dives a little deeper into the supernatural elements of the series. Large array of special features.

Surprising twists/turns this season and, yet again, main characters get killed off.  Episode 4 had the best ending, IMO. But due to the Con below keep the fast forward button handy while watching this season.

The only Con is the same as last season: This could be a 5 star series all the way, but it has too many explicit scenes depicting brutality/depravity towards women/children/etc. This season was a bit worse than the last. Removed 2 stars from rating for this. They need to show less/imply more because these scenes are seriously hurting the overall brilliance displayed in every other part of this series.

Actually I just started watching last fall and binged watched all 6 seasons.....I wanted to know what the big deal was....I ALMOST did not get through the first season because there was SO MUCH pornography and violence...rape and slitting the horse throat really threw me over the edge. However, with that being said, I did finish it because the story is phenomenal, the sets are amazing, the costumes are breath taking....and the acting is well pretty darn good...I was disappointed with the unnecessary pornographic sex and extreme violence. The story is so great and a lot of those situations could be "implied" rather than camera in your face stuff. I thought HBO could have told the story without all the graphic violence and still maintained a phenomenal fantastical story.  It could have been right up there with Lord of the Rings.....Unfortunately they chose to cheapen it.  I'm still going to watch it though and have nervous breakdowns and switch it off when my daughter  walks in the room.

NEW REVIEW:

No one is perfect; even TheMADhatter makes mistakes, on rare occasions.  I had previously given GOT (Game of Thrones, in case you're living under a rock, and aren't familiar with the acronym) two stars, and criticized it for falling into the pitfalls and ailments common to other TV series.  (READ BELOW TO SEE MY PREVIOUS REVIEW).

I COULD NOT HAVE BEEN MORE WRONG!  At the end of season three, I came to be under the impression that the writers of this show were "winging" the story, in an effort to drag the show on.  At that point, based on the plot and flow of the story, I was under the impression that the writers of this show were not following a set story, but were falling into the same recipe for failure that previous TV series like Surface, Hereos, and Lost adopted.

As I said in my previous review, these shows clearly did not have a set story, from the outset, with a beginning, a middle, and an end.  Instead, each one simply started with an idea, and then the writers simply continued to expand and convolute the story to keep it going for as long as possible, until the Networks decided to cancel them (after only a single season, in the case of Surface).  On the other hand, what made the TV Series "ROME" so good was that - unlike these others -  the TV show was commissioned with a set story, from the outset.  This meant that, instead of each episode being written by a different writer causing the show's story to spin out of control, each individual episode and the overall story were harmonious and congruent.

As I said, at the end of season 3 of GOT, it appeared to me that the writers were stretching and expanding the story to keep the series running for as long as possible.  HOWEVER, this was not the case.

After swearing off the show, I ended up coming back to it, and watching seasons 4, 5, 6, & now 7.  I now realize that what I took for shallow, melodramatic, writing, was - in fact - intricately complex and well-thought-out writing.  The writers of GOT did have a set story from the outset, with a beginning, a middle, and an end, and they never strayed from it ... not even once.  Not only did they have a set story from the outset, it is a remarkably well-written and intricately complex story.

At the end of season 3 I had thought the writing was getting sloppy and that the show would end up leaving many issues it had raised unanswered.  In fact, the story was far more detailed than I had realized, and it eventually answers every question or issue ever raised in great, precise, detail.  The detail of the story is along the lines of JRR Tolkien's Silmarillion.

I've become so used to the poor writing commonly dribbled out of Hollywood, that I never imagined that this show would include such a precisely written and harmonious story, but that is exactly what the GOT story involves.

When I wrote my critical review below, after only 3 seasons, I was not far enough into the story to yet appreciate its complexity.

LEARN FROM MY MISTAKE PEOPLE:  If you don't like GOT and find yourself being critical of it ... it is probably because you do not understand it yet.  Keep watching to the end, and then draw your conclusion.  My conclusion is that GOT is a superbly written show, and that it is the best show to have been released in the recent past.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
MY PREVIOUS REVIEW (Where I gave it two stars):

I'm done watching this show.  If you're wondering when I quit, it was Season 3, episode 9.  I'll avoid including any spoilers, but let me just say that I enjoyed watching it until the show betrayed the viewers.  Once a show betrays its viewers, I QUIT!

There are three types of people in this world. 1) People who watch TV series; 2) People who HATE TV series and never watch them; and 3) People who will watch TV series ONLY when they don't suffer from the typical ailments common to the genre.

Personally, I'm in the third category.  It took almost all the way through the Third Season, before it was clear to me that I was WASTING MY TIME!

I've only made it through a few TV series, from start to finish.  Rome, by Showtime, was an excellent TV series.  Why was it so good?  Because it wasn't just written to keep people blindly watching each week.  It had a start, and a finish and a story in-between, all written BEFORE they ever started shooting the first episode.  IN other words, it was written like a long movie.

Take another TV series, the show "HEROES."  I watched this series as well.  Episode after episode ,waiting for the villain to finally meet his match and be killed.  However, it never happened.  Instead, after watching hours and hours of the show, when the showdown finally happened, the showdown I had been waiting for, for episode after episode, the show threw all of its established "rules" out the window, and let villain win.

Why?  Who knows.  Probably because they knew that millions of people were also watching waiting for him to be defeated, and the TV networks decided it was their cash cow.  Why create a new cash cow.  If the people are all watching because they want to see him finally destroyed, then - why - we'll just never kill him. I quit watching the show immediately, as did all of my friends.  Aside from the fact that the show was now absurd, it was obvious to me "why" the network was doing it.

Shows like Heroes and Lost were NEVER coherent pieces of fiction.  Instead, they were both contradicting pieces of garbage, whose story lines were constantly manipulated by TV network executives, whose only goal was to milk out as many viewers as they could THAT WEEK, with no regard to the viewer  in terms of producing a quality long-term show.

SLIGHT SPOILER ALERT IN THE NEXT PARAGRAPH:

Well, here we go again.  You might as well take every character you care about, from the ENTIRE FIRST THREE SEASONS of this show, and just assume they are all going to die.  After watching three seasons, you will feel like it was a COMPLETE WASTE OF YOUR TIME.  By the end of season three, the show is just like the others.  A mixed up hodge-podge bunch of garbage, with a million storylines running simultaneously, NONE OF WHICH EVER REACHES A SATISFACTORY FINISH!!  NEVER!  IT JUST DRONES ON AND ON, and after three seasons you CARE ABOUT NO ONE OR ANYTHING ABOUT THIS SHOW.

I quit.  The wedding scene, at the end.  Well, it just showed me that these writers, for this show as well, have no regard for betraying the viewer.

For the show itself, 5 stars wouldn't be enough.  I think it's extraordinary.  But I'm rating the DVD sets here.  I purchased Seasons 1-6 as the separate sets, have watched them all and I'm just shocked and frankly angry at what poor quality these are.  The picture is just awful, particularly in scenes that are dark.  Think VHS quality.  I do not exaggerate. And it's every season, though oddly enough, some episodes are worse than others.

I really don't understand this.  I have many other shows on DVD, including HBO ones, and none of them are like this.  Muddy, blotchy, artifact-laden image quality, and sometimes even skipping.  For disclaimer's sake no, it is not my player, not my TV (I've tried them on a few players and screens), and these are the legit, licensed sets.

Then there's the packaging itself.  The "fat" sets that fold out with a disk on each page (versus the "stacked disk" sets) are also crap.  The plastic disk holders have a tendency to come unglued from the cardboard backings. I've heard others mention the same issue.  Again, I have other sets with a similar design and this doesn't happen with those.  What the heck is going on with the quality control where they're making these?  GoT deserves better.

Anyway, I can't recommend buying these.  And considering some of the problems I've heard with the BluRay disks, too (and my own negative experiences with BluRay players which makes me steer clear of converting over to that format), I'm not tempted to purchase again.  I'd recommend renting the shows instead and save your money, perhaps check a local library for them.  I may, in fact, donate my sets, as I'm not sure I could stand watching them again.

P.S.  Amazon, FFS, keep the different media and edition review sections SEPARATE!

I really like the show but not sure I'm ready to spend $99 on the newer seasons especially considering other popular shows on networks have 5-8 more episodes more per season.

Need to bring this up off the bat. Series three for me contained more scenes of gore, torture and psychological catastrophes than any of the series before it, it also contained the usual amount of nudity and swear words... so how is this the season that's rated a 15 when the previous seasons were 18s? Its mad! I digress.
Definitely the strongest season so far with more twists and turns, betrayals and life changing events. Introducing a few new characters, namely the evil Ramsey Snow of house Bolton (If you thought Joffrey was bad wait until you get a load of this lunatic). As previously quiet and obedient houses and bannermen begin to make a mark for themselves on westeros.

Stannis licks his wounds after his defeat in season two, becoming ever more obsessed with his new God and the Red Woman Melisandre, desperately trying to recuperate and get back in the game as a contender for the throne. Making life hard for his ever suffering but loyal second in command Davos as he attempts to reason with his Zealot obsessed king. Davos is such a likeable character and his loyalty to Stannis is both heart warming and heart breaking as we watch Davos desperately play off and counter the many savage suggestions of the religious Melisandre, with great chemistry between all three characters you can feel the tension in the room with every scene as the two confidants battle for their kings mind which is forever unbalanced and as likely to take either side depending on his mood.

Daenerys begins her liberation of slavers bay quickly gaining momentum and power throughout the series in the way only the dragon born can, quickly becoming the most powerful character in the show, gathering more and more allies to her cause, she becomes seemingly unstoppable, yet remains one of the viewers favourite candidates for the throne as she shows again and again compassion and fairness for the people she comes into contact with, really becoming the light in this dark world. Followed by her loyal and love struck aid Jorah he also has new challenges to face as he finds himself in competition with the new allies flocking to her side, including the humiliated Commander of the Kings Guard from season one Ser Barristen Selmy and the handsome Daario Naharis of the Second Sons mercenaries.

Robb Stark once again faces betrayal as he attends his grandfathers funeral in River Run, introducing us at last to the Tullys including the humorous Blackfish and the Mr Bean of Westeros; Edmure Tully. Watching Robb struggle to handle the political aspect is quite sad as we watch the young wolf, who has never lost a battle decline purely due to his lack of political leadership and his restricting honour, both marching him towards a fate like his fathers. The similarities between Ned and Robb become more apparent as he makes foolish decisions all in vain attempts to do the right thing or make up for mistakes made, all culminating in one of the most memorable and terrible scenes of the entire show.

Theon Greyjoy, probably has the worst time of it in this season, after his betrayal of Robb in season two he finds himself captured by an unknown assailant and very very violently tortured both Physically and psychologically as well as mutilated, forever distorting and changing the character into somebody entirely new. Despite his betrayals and actions in season two you really begin to feel for the character again very early on, even forgiving his actions as he confesses how he really feels about himself and is made the play thing of the sadistic Ramsey Snow. Some fantastic acting done by both actors in all of their scenes really making for a horrible experience for viewers, i fear this may be the last season we ever see Theon Greyjoy...

Tyrion continues to play the game in kings landing, battling with his sister for their fathers approval who has now taken his place as Hand of the King. Tyrion now has a harder time keeping his head above water, struck from all his power by his father, Tyrion is left vulnerable to the cruelty of Joffrey who continues to enjoy torturing his subjects. Watching him keep his composure under such odds and witnessing the cruelty of his father first hand, Tyrion remains a solid favourite of the fans, who after his heroes exploits in season two deserves a lot more than he gets in this season.

Jon Snow follows his new Wildling lifestyle while ever secretly looking for an opportunity to escape back to his fellow men of the nights watch, Jon Snow begins to realise the real threat to Westeros and begins to understand that the only way to win the real war is unity... something nobody else wants. Breaking his nights watch vows and literally skating on real thin ice Jon begins to craft himself as the hero Westeros needs.

Jaime Lannister continues life as captive, with the ever honourable and faithful Brienne charged with transporting him the two run into all sorts of adventures on their way to Kings Landing, including run ins with not so honourable Stark Soldiers, farmers and then the sadistic soldiers of house Bolton and their leader Lock. Survival looks bleak for the pair and as Jaime attempts his usual charm and smarmy talk to get out of a situation it backfires changing his life forever, if he survives.

Overall, definitely the best season so far, completely shifting the power around the country and countless heartbreaking revelations and moments, this is the defining season that will make and break lifelong fans, if you though the execution of Ned Stark was the pinnacle of Game of Thrones, that seems like child's play after this season.

My husband and I were quickly captivated in season 1 episode 1 by the character development and story line.  It became increasingly difficult to continue watching however, given the over the top sex and violence.  Felt like we were watching porn at times and the violence overpowered seemingly everything else.  We hit the end point on the "Red Wedding" episode.  Violence and sexual content definitely has its place, but we were often left wondering that shows such as these help fuel real life violence when this kind of entertainment has the ability to desensitize individuals.  It must take some questionable personalities in terms of writers, producers to execute these shows with such perverted, violent cinematography.  In reading the online chatter, apparently we are not alone in our views.  We are so sorry to bow out of what is a cultural phenomenon and other wise would be a great source of entertainment for us.  To the producers:  please, please consider what you put out to your viewers, many of whom are young and still forming their psyche's.  I am a child psychologist and my husband a 40 year high school history teacher.

I bought this mainly for the collectible steelbook and magnet.

 MULTIPLE COPIES 
You get three different copies of the series:
1) Blu-ray (physical discs)
2) UltraViolet 1080p HD version (digital copy, HD only available on some devices)
3) iTunes 1080p HD version (digital copy)

The digital code gives you two digital versions (which is rare and appreciated).

 STEELBOOK and MAGNET 
This steelbook has artwork designed by Elastic, the agency that created the Emmy Award-winning opening credits, and has a magnet on the cover that can be removed and used as a regular magnet, or left on to show off as a collector's piece. Each season represents one of the major houses of the series, and this season three steelbook represents House Frey with The Twins bridge as its sigil on the magnet. The steelbook is in a matching decorative plastic outer case that holds the magnet in place so it doesn't scratch the steelbook. Depending on how this was shipped, this plastic may or may not be cracked as I've seen a lot of cracked plastic cases with the steelbook intact.

 THE SHOW 
The show is greatin acting, in storytelling, in visuals, in music, and in writing. I've watched everything at least three times, and there are so many new things you see when re-watching, and with the knowledge of future episodes. The third season has a lot of incredible shocks you won't see coming, and some that are very much foreshadowed to those that pay attention. It will certainly be one of the most memorable seasons you will ever watch on television.

I have converted many friends who previously used to think this was about "dungeons and dragons and lord of the rings," (like I did) who are now *all* addicted to the show. If you don't already know, this show isn't about what you think it may be about.

This is currently THE only good show on television, and if you don't like it, you probably don't understand good television (sorry, not sorry). It has been the number one torrented show in every single year since it came out for a reason (which is a blessing and curse for the producers). After watching this, everything else on TV becomes: "why I am watching all these other crappy shows?"

This is one of those series that I will buy the individual season sets, and whatever big box set comes out in the future. GAME OF THRONES! Recommended.

I would say the series is finally getting a lot better. My main complaint of cutting off scenes too quickly and not letting them play out has vastly improved. We also get more politics (mostly via marriage alliances) intrigue as well as Dragon Lady finally getting a personality as the benevolent freedom dragon rider.

I know the Red Wedding is the big shocker but by 2016 as I watched this for the first time even knowing it was going to happen, thank goodness it did. I was tired of the depressing and politically naive Starks from Season One onwards especially Queenie Catelyn. The only Starks worth watching are still alive--Air-Ya Jordan and Sansabelt. The other, Riccon is just there (why is he even in this as he adds zero to the plot?). His brother, Bran Flake, now sees stuff in his dreams and is joined by the Love Actually Boy now grown up having Liam Neeson apparently letting him wander Westeros. All that stuff set in the North and the Wall with the Wildings, the White Walkers and anything with a W in it simply is a bore. Just get us back to the cities of the South, please, where the sun shines and people don't just meander around landscape.

Jon Snow (who apparently must be referred to by his full name all the time) falls in love with the girl from Pixar's Brave whom I call Scottish Highland Lassie. Their banter is the only entertaining thing about the land where snow is everywhere and I keep thinking about the Echo & the Bunnymen's cover shot for their album Porcupine. Although, having said that, I do enjoy Rollie Pollie Boy of the Knight's (or is it Night's?) Watch, but the woman and her baby he saves are kind of a bland canvas.

At least now we learn what the people who have ships and live on islands are like. The conclusion: Just as boring as the Starks. Sure the Fire Lady giving birth to a Smoke Monster is odd, but I liked her much better when she was in Holland during the Nazi Occupation in Black Book (a terrific movie made in 2006 prior to Europe turning into the Medieval Age in 2011 with Plate Of Scones).

Oh, yeah, that Theon (or Theoff) Greynojoy becomes a dillwad, gets his comeuppance and now there's a bigger d-bag than him in Reese's Pieces Bolton Wanderers who is basically a psychotic torturer. That whole story thread I could do without. Kill the both of them off quickly, please.

Other than that, it takes way too long before the Girts' High School Gym Teacher Knight to get Jaime Spelled Wrong Lameystairs back to King's Landing. We need more Ham-ez Now One Hand-ister in Season Four. Old Emma Peel now shows up and looks like we need more of her as she's got a quick wit and who knows, maybe John Steed will show up as well.

Anyway, most of the Starks are toast, one war is done and the dragons got bigger. Even so the Snow Zombies will kill everyone in the end unless global warming speeds the heck up.

The extras on this DVD box set are lame vs. Season Two's excellent extras--usual commentary tracks, deleted/extended and extremely short look at the borefest Wildlings (I think I don't love you because you do not make anything groovy) and the whole marriage/political alliance in case you fell asleep back in PoliSci 101 or Medieval Fantasyland 205.

Game of Thrones. Need I say more? No. But I will. I got hooked on this show awhile back. It had already been out for some time and I was able to binge watch (which is always good for me). Let me tell you, I was hooked. I love the intricate characters, the ever changing story and multiple plot lines. You are never bored watching this show.

I will say that if you are an emotional TV viewer, such as myself (I am a cryer and get connected easily with characters) you will find yourself in tears, raging mad and upset throughout the show. The point is, it is a good enough show to draw you in and make you part of the experience.

This show has left me soaring, left me sad, made me angry, made me cry, made me laugh, made my day. It is thought provoking and entertaining all at the same time. Love it.

I just can not get enough of these Game of Thrones programs.  The HBO teams selected talented actors, wrote an amazing script, and production values are outstanding.  Like the books, story and character development are exceptional.  I've read all the books twice, so I do know what is going to happen with the story.  Still, it is delightful to SEE the characters, the settings, and the action on screen.  This is very unlike me; I usually read a great book and find I'm not interested in seeing the movie.  HBO's Thrones programs ALL offer GIFTED actors and quality production features -- these programs are just so outstanding, I can't help myself!  I am looking forward to getting CDs from ALL seasons ... and, of course, for the new books to come out ... WAY OVER DUE.

What more can, or needs to, be said about this monumental series.  It's intense but if you can handle the rough spots, there's drama, humor, character and plot development there a-plenty.  This is really a television landmark that has changed the way I think about the medium.

Lord of the Rings for grownups. Brilliant writing, casting, cinematography, costumes, set design, special effects and acting. Totally immersive. Some of the best written dialogue -- much of it witty and laugh-out-loud funny -- ever to appear on any screen of whatever size. Shot with the verve and scale of a Hollywood Technicolor movie of old. A lot of swordplay, grizzly deaths, bloodshed and sex. But all of it excellently choreographed and photographed, with much of the action being unexpected and engrossing. G.O.T. is a fully realized alternate time, place and world. And it has lots of smart things to say about power, politics, ambition, the human heart and the human species capacity for both cruelty and nobility. Also, the supernatural creatures (White Walkers, e.g.) are vivid and realistic, and the dragons, onscreen neither too much nor too little, are freaking awesome!

Aside from my problems with the deviations from the books, my big problem is with the quality and design of the Blu-rays. There is no memory (if you press stop, you have to start over from the beginning every time, you can't press play and continue from where you left off), and every disc advertises special features in the menu that you can click on which aren't on that disc. If you "play all" episodes, when they are over, it tells you to put in the next disc. If you go back to the main menu, you can't hit "play all" again - it just says to put in the next disc. After watching all of the episodes, I like to watch through with commentary, which means that I then have to go through episode by episode. For the price, I would think that HBO could put in some of the basic features we have come to expect on DVDs/Blu-rays.

A lot of good people die, but so do a lot of bad people. I sometimes feel like I should volunteer as a helper at the morgue for this series. But this series is beyond reproach. I have not read the books and have no intention of doing so. I read history, literature, mythology, poetry, you get the picture. But as a diversion from the hard work of reading, this series is the non-pareil. And it's a benchmark for production values. And the acting is uniformly excellent. Of course, adventure stories, whether set on the ancient past, the present or the future essentially follow the scenario I associate with STAR TREK., namely, the plot is one goddam thing after another. But when the cast includes actors of the caliber of Peter Dinklage, Ian Glen, Glenna Headley, Emilia Clarke, Charles Dance, etc. ad infinitum (sic), the intriques, set-backs, romances, ambushes, intimacies, arguments, whirligigs, fights and battles, curious lore, etc. ad infinitum, all fall into their archetypal niches, and we hardly feel any guilt in pursuing this guilty pleasure. It's really that good. One sign of its excellence. As the credits roll by for each episode the music playing behind them has been composed to fit the mood and extend it in  our minds. And there are surprises: after the episode when the wedding party is murdered in a horrific mass murder, including Rob's pregnant wife and the Matriarch herself, the credits rolled by in absolute silence. That shows a production team which is really paying attention. I have the highest respect for their creativity and integrity. These episodes have been among televisions's finest hours. I mean that in complete sincerity.

Season 3 develops and expands themes and plots. I was disappointed in season 2 as it seemed too complex, with too many short-scripted plots. At least in season 3, some of those plots are more comprehensible. The power of Kalisi is expanding as well as her humanity. I fear for Sansa, who doesn't seem to have the hutzpa to protect herself...hopefully she will "get smart".  Jon Snow's part seems to be fading in the early episodes of season 3, wonder what will become of him?  Movement and consolidation of kingdoms towards a common enemy seems to be moving in that direction. Still, there is quite a lot of confusion with so many kingdoms. Love the locations, scenery, costumes and cinematography. The programs appear to have cost a lot to set up. In the long run, I think this program (Seasons 1,2,3 will be among my classic collection). I have season 4 but have not watched it yet. May go back to season 2 for clarification before advancing.  Still, I remain disappointed in the porno as it does not advance the stories and seems unnecessarily distracting to the progress of themes and plots. (Not in the books as my grand child has told me.)

I'm sorry. I know lots of people love this series. I'm not sure we are watching the same show. This show is slow, ponderous, predictable and boring. It's seems to be designed for pre-adolescents and adolescent boys. The plots are stupid and simple. The Starks seem incredibly naive, clumsy and dumb. The Lannisters are also dumb and perverted, homicidal maniacs. In fact, the first and only response to every character in the show seems to be to kill someone in the most brutal, sadistic way possible as an answer to every problem. How long would any of these people survive in the real world? How would they deal with a plague like what happened back in the real Middle Ages? Stab it? By the way, the weapons used are primitive. Apparently everyone in Westeros is too stupid to have invented gunpowder the way China did in the Middle Ages. Any thoughtful or scholarly person in this show is presented as weak, female or gay. Real men and women in this show only know how to kill, get drunk and/or have sex with anyone and anything. The action is minimal. Women are all treated like second class citizens or slaves. There is no humor in it at all. The atmosphere is always grey, dull and dismal. There's a lot of nudity, sex and violence thrown in for purely gratuitous reasons that have nothing to do with the story. It takes forever for anything significant to happen. Also, why is everyone British? Isn't this supposed to be a mythical place with all different types of people? No wizards or witches either. No. The Red Woman doesn't count. Those special effects are sooo expensive. That's why they never have any. If you want to put yourself to sleep this show is for you or you can try more grown-up entertainment elsewhere.
Finally, has anyone who writes fantasy or science fiction ever heard of the word democracy? No. What  Dragon Queen's offers of freedom is not democracy. She still expects the people she frees to serve her instead in her war of unification. They are just exchanging one master for another. Why is everything in these shows based on a feudal type government? The writers of these books, movies and shows need more imagination.

If you're looking at reviews of season three then it is inevitable that you're already captivated by this epic masterpiece of TV fantasy. We re-watched seasons one and two as a bit of essential preparative revision and have, as with previous seasons, watched this one twice back-to-back. A second viewing is essential, especially as we have a whole raft of new characters, to really get to enjoy the fiendish complexity of the interwoven narrative threads. Some very minor spoilers follow in the next paragraph

The seven kingdoms of Wersteros become ever more disparate as the civil war continues with Rob Stark leading the men of the North against the unspeakable King Joffrey while nobody is paying any attention to events north of the wall with Jon Snow as the Wildlings head south against the inexorable approach of winter and concomitant White Walkers. At the same time, Daenerys with attendant splendid dragons is trying to raise an army to help restore the Targaryen throne while Stannis licks his metaphorical wounds and falls further under the thrall of the red witch. That just covers the main story arcs. Add into that mix Aryas journey and the Brotherhood Without Banners, Jamie Lannister & Brienne and Brans very separate quests, the ascendancy Margaery Tyrell and, as ever, the irrepressibly brilliant Tyrion and the improbably likeable Varys hold Kings Landing together as things are not all sweetness and light in the house of Lannister.

There is just so much going on in so many places that it is impossible to grasp all of the subtleties even after a second viewing. Just for a change, there is a really useful Blu-ray special feature  the in episode guide allows you to see who is doing what where; really handy on the first viewing with so many new characters to keep track of.

With a lot of getting from A to B and a lack of set piece scenes, this season gives the feeling of getting all of the chess pieces in the right place ready for a tumultuous fourth season. Thats not to say, however, that there aren't more than a few surprises along the way. Well done, again, HBO  splendid stuff.

Incredible show, incredible production value, and an excellent cast. Season three veers off from the books in places but I think it actually does so in a positive way. The books have a tendency to go through long, looping storylines with throwaway characters (don't get me wrong, I love the books) whereas the show attempts (more so in season 3 than in previous seasons) to forge its own path, in some cases simplifying overcomplicated messes that G.R.R. Martin wrote himself into a corner with.

I see the show and the books as two separate and distinct things, and I enjoy both equally. Season three of the show really ramps up a lot of stuff that has been brewing so far, and I doubt anyone who has gotten this far into watching the show wouldn't love this season.

The blu-ray/DVD combo and digital copy are a great value; you can lend the DVD copy out to friends while keeping the blu-ray, and the digital copy allows you to download a copy onto iTunes while also having a copy on other streaming video services.

I love A Song of Ice and Fire, but merely like the show. I know they have limited budgets, and multiple locations across the world, and make up and effects are expensive, but some scenes just are not as grand in scope as they are in the book, and those who are described as hideously disfigured merely have little scars. Also, it is a bit disconcerting how much older most of the characters are in the show. Children who are supposed to be 13 and 14 look like they are 18 or even 20. Gratuitous violence replaces the consequences of the actual violence described in the books. Some aspects of the book, particularly those that deal more directly with magic, were better left out or minimized. Personally I hope we do not see Lady Stoneheart in the show, and as little of her as possible in future books.

Extraordinary storyline and amazing characters. The meta message of this series like so many other great works of American cinema is the history of the battle of democracy against tyranny. This one, however, is just a bit more bloody and with more women and people who are savagely exploited. The savagery, is frankly, probably rather realistic of a time hundreds of years ago in real human history.
But this story includes magic. Dragons. Demons. Witches. No doubt is what people believed hundreds of years ago. So, in a manner of speaking this story has the ring of truth to it. A classic epic struggle wrapped in stunningly beautiful and ugly people and creatures. It makes for an addicting distraction.

Just amazing...you have to experience the Game of Thrones phenomenon yourself, even knowing the spoilers and what is to come does not dull the impact from this great show. The only "negative" I can think of are the sex scenes, as they sometimes get in the way of the story (to me) and make it kind of awkward to watch with friends/family, but I get why they are there, this show demonstrates the human element, so it brutally let's viewers see the heights of it's greatness and the depths of its wickedness. So, every aspect of what makes us human including our sexuality is explored and shown (graphically) but it does not feel exploitative to me. In other words, the disturbing violence and adult themes (incest, rape, murder, prostitution, etc) are not presented merely for shock value but to highlight how the characters respond to these injustices as the victims and as the perpetrators. Some might feel angered by certain characters dying ***SPOILERS***
i.e. Rob Stark, his wife, his mother, the Starks in general (not the luckiest bunch eh?)
but that is part of what makes this show brilliant, it plays with our expectations and serves as a deconstruction of the medieval fantasy genre. For example, I never thought I could ever, even for a moment root for a character like Jaime Lannister, that is, until what I say him face this season and last. Granted, I am not sure if the deconstruction aspects were intentional by the original author, he may have just wanted to write a great story but I can't tell you how many times I have been surprised with how expertly the show manages to show you that no one is truly good, they just have an agenda and rules they are comfortable with, some (the Lannisters) are more...ah hem...let's just say "comfortable"...doing whatever it takes to further their power, whereas others limit themselves and the show genuinely shows what happens when the honorable face evil doers with clout. This doesn't diminish the beauty of trying to be an honorable person but merely realistically shows the consequences.

When I try to compare this to a REAL TV show that is CLASSIC with UNFORGETTABLE characters who DEVELOP, stories that are memorable, and LESSONS TO BE LEARNED such as Star Trek The Next Generation I can't believe I used to think this show was even "good."

I DON'T remember 1 episode that taught me a valuable life lesson.  Therefore to me it is GARBAGE, a waste of time, RANDOM ENTERTAINMENT at best.  And to me THE BEST movies, tv shows, and music make you think and connect and learn.  Game of Thrones DOES NOT do these things.

Yes there is drama, random entertainment and violence, and wonderful sets and costumes.  BUT at the end of the day it is a WASTE of time.  Don't believe me?  Try reading the book and I BET you won't finish the series and at some point wonder "Why am I wasting my time reading this?"

The HBO television series "Game of Thrones" is notorious for its gratuitous nudity and violence, and it does rest on the shoulders of a magnificent series of books by George Martin.  But the showrunners do deserve credit for a passionate commitment to storytelling, and while the dialogue can be melodramatic at times it is still sharp writing and wit.

In Season 3, we also see the television series achieving a life outside the books, and the characters themselves are achieving personalities that were not envisioned originally in the books.  This is both good and bad.  The Tyrells are portrayed and developed magnificently in the television series, achieving a rich layered complexity previously unseen in the books.  But the Starks are far more annoying and self-righteous that I had previously remembered in the books.

This show is my favorite show on television.  If you haven't watched Game of Thrones, it is worth knowing it has some scenes of strong brutal violence as well as some scenes of sex and a fair amount of nudity.  However, that's not what the show revolves around by any means.  This show is very character driven; however, many main characters end up dying, and that's just something you'll have to get used to.  The book readers sometimes have their complaints about the show, but hey, let's face it:  books and tv/movies are different and have to be done differently.  I mean Harry Potter wasn't exactly true to the books every time, but I still love the movies.  So it is what it is, regardless of how close Game of Thrones truly follows the "A Song of Ice and Fire" books by George RR Martin (I believe that's what they're called).  Anyways, I've been watching GOT from the first season, and I have loved every episode from the start.  I can't wait for the next season to come out, and I buy every season on DVD or BluRay as soon as they're available just to enjoy each full season at least one more time.  If you like excellent dialogue, cunning wit, hateful villains, questionable "good guys", peculiar motives, lots of shadiness and backstabbing, etc, all within a superbly acted and directed show of different people and groups all fighting for power within a realm of darkness and just the right amount of fantasy, then Game of Thrones is for you.  But do yourself a favor and start from the beginning so you know what the hell is going on, lol.

While this series seems promising with a brilliant cast of actors, it is unfortunately riddled with what amounts to pornography, extreme nudity, homosexuals have sex, and lesbians engaging in sex.  The plot and lines are beautifully played.  However, the series is not rated for viewing.  Therefore, if you are looking for a great series to share with friends and family, be forewarned that the nudity scenes last for several minutes and are not a passing glance.  The scenes are offensive, lasting in duration, and unacceptable for viewing.  It would have been a great series for all ages if it would have foregone the heavy amounts of nudity and soft porn.  It is a shame really because the cast is first rate actors and the scenery is excellent.  I would not recommend this series to anyone, especially people who have a higher moral character.  You can not keep up with the plot because you have to fast forward too many nudity/sex scenes.  We watched most of the first season, but as the sex scenes/nudity became worse and worse, we threw it in the trash.  We have returned the two other seasons unopened.

The Game of Thrones is probably closer to historical verity than we would wish it to be; But, dramatizing good and evil so effectively, might just help us learn some of the lessons our society should have taught us the hard way, over time,

In a time when most people are struggling to eat Amazon decides to up the anty to 99$.  For what?  I'm quitting prime because of this.  I don't want free music to stream, I want to pay 79$ for prime! I thought 79$ was too much! Amazon is has turned into walmart.  Anyone remember when super walmart first came out it was so clean and the people who worked there so educated and friendly?  Remember when they had a three customers in a line a new cash register will be opened policy?  Remember when walmart used to stock their shelves in the middle of the night instead of during the busiest time of the day?  Remember when made in America was their slogan?  Now that they drove all the mom and pop stores out of business look at walmart.  The stores are filthy, a lot of the people who work their look and act like they just got out of prison, the isles are always crammed with huge pallets to be stocked during the busiest times, and everything is Chinese.  Also, the prices aren't any better than anyone elses.  Walmart is a bully.  Amazon has gotten a little too big for it's britches and is getting just like walmart.  I find the prices better elsewhere and that makes up more than enough for shipping.  Plus, most online vendors give free shipping over 50$ anyway.  Good luck Amazon!  I hope scalping from publishers and customers serves you well in the future.

We've now watched season 1, 2, and 3 and can't wait until we can buy season 4.  Since we don't pay for HBO, we have to wait until the season is over and is released in order to watch it.  We decided to watch season 1, 1st episode to see what all the hype was about, we were hooked from that moment on and basically had a Game of Thorns marathon over the next couple of weeks until we watched ever available episode.  We got very caught up with the characters, and both my husband and I had our favorites.  We routed for the good guys, and were disappointed and shocked when things didn't go their way.  Lots of violence, sex, and stress, saying that, you either get very caught up in it, or you hate it.  My husband and I loved it.  My folks didn't, it was too much for them. I highly recommend Game of Thrones for all you strong movies goers who love action, can keep up with a fast story line, and have the stomach for what seems so real on the big screen.

I've noticed that several of the reviews here are about the series and not the actual product. I am not going to review the series here. For that, you can always check out IMDB, which is where a review of the series belongs. Here I want to address the actual, physical DVDSthe things you purchased or are planning to purchase from Amazon. As others have noted, the DVDs are problematic. In my case, they did play, but took a long time to load, and often rebooted if I only played the first episode on the disc, then tried to play the second episode later. I suspect this has to do with some rather ill-advised attempts at copy protection, thus punishing the legitimate buyers while doing virtually nothing to stem piracy. Three stars because they did play, but no more considering the problems and lag time it took for them to do so.

GoT Season three is a great adaptation, full of riveting performances, breath-taking sets, costumes and effects, but most importantly, with a shocking and addictive plot based on "A Storm of Swords", which is the most appraised book in the books. The producers, directors and their teams made a great job adapting the book to the series.
Great series. I have also read all of the books and it follow books fairly well. My only complaint is that I have to wait so long for the next season.

After hearing a lot of great remarks about this series i decided to give it a chance, Thank the seven gods i did, Great actors, great characters, great villains, fight scenes that make you jump out of your chair and through objects in anger, This series grabs your emotion and plays with it. i would recommend to watch this series that has turned to one of my favorites.

Our adult grandchildren have found this series fascinating and are watching it also.  Thanks Amazon.

I've read the books and decided to buy the TV Shows based on the reviews. I must say that I wasn't disappointed. The series is historically accurate, the quality of the DVD/Blu-ray discs very good. But want to make couple of points here:

1. The actual TV Shows are available only in DVD format and not blu-ray, at least, not in this selection. The blu-ray discs are additional material (loads of them) that are equally fascinating.
2. The Digital Copy DOES NOT work in many countries, including India, so it is actually a waste to procure one with a Digital Copy, that is till such archaic rules are removed by broadcasting companies. So legally you CANNOT download the Digital Copy if you reside outside of the US and a very few countries of Europe.
3. When I made this point with Amazon Customer Care that Amazon knew the contents and also the fact that I was shipping to India so they could very well have not shipped this collection with the Digital Copy. Amazon Customer Care agreed to make a partial refund of the total cost back to my credit card. That is one of the many reasons why shopping on Amazon is such a delightful experience.
I love this series!!! I was thrilled to receive this special edition, everyone who sees it on my shelf is in excited to look at it!
gory bloody , intense yet it great  with the plots within plots plans with in plans .. worth watching  enjoy

The best T.V show of all times is clearly by far a Game of Thrones.

It has all the action that you need, beautiful women and it is set in a fantasy world where your imagination can go wild.
The action consists of battles for the throne, Dragons flying about and swords constantly clashing. It shows the blood and all the gore making it that much better. Just in the first few episodes alone the George R. R. Martin whom is the writer captivates your imagination and will have you feeling as if you are directly in the fight. The Characters are so well played that it is inspiring to the imagination, has you thinking about the possibilities.
 The main reason I kept watching the show was seeing how beautiful the princess and the queens where. I know that they have professional make up artist and the lighting is modified so that they look their best, but even with all of the enhancers their beauty still keeps me interested.
 Now the setting is in a fantasy world but it also has a hint of medieval times. Everybody once in their lives has dreamed about ruling their own castle, leading men in battle with swords and shields instead of guns like in todays world. Well this shows makes you feel a bit closer to that dream. Now if you aren't into these types of shows I suggest you watch it and see if you don't change your mind.

Game of  Thrones will satisfy all your T.V watching craving needs with its beauty, blood and gore and the setting will make you a king.

I bought the first two seasons and couldn't wait for this one to be available. I am fascinated by the series. I watch it from the beginning to refresh my memory of characters, the cities and who belongs with who. Just love the show. I'm a big fan.

Same quality and excellent delivery service as the other seasons 1 and  2 as I had purchased
previously.
I was hooked by the intrigue presented in the story lines and am impatiently waiting for season 4 to come out on DVD.
What more can you say about the greatest series on cable....Arrived on time without flaws. Liked the combination of DVD, Bluray, and Digital.

Great season and great buy. The special features and behind the scene features add much more to your viewing experience and deeper understanding of what the directors/showrunners were trying to do. I always seem to appreciate the shows more after understanding all the work, thought, and emotions that many different people put in to create this one fantastic show. The audio commentary too are also fantastic to listen too.  The discs bring you much knowledge and fill in some gaps better for those who have not read the book.

The DVD and Digital copies are also a very nice addition to this package. I am able to give my parents the DVD, which to this point still has Chinese subtitles, so they can understand the show even better. The digital copies are nice to have so I can bring it anywhere!

I am a huge GOT's fan so I had to get this when it came out. I have it displayed in my office!

we already own seasons 1 and 2.this was season three and was not packaged very well.i love the show and the price at amazon cannot be beat.i love this series and will order again in the future

Awesome in all manners, I heard about this show from my son and I was NOT disappointed by this spectacular illustration of REAL talent....It has element's of plot, script and visual stimulation that will NEVER leave us wanting....Except for more.

If you haven't heard about GOT, this review won't get you to it.  But if you have, this set of disks is well worth the dollars.  Beware:  you will become obsessed and have to buy the other seasons as well.
I'm a "Throner."  Can't wait for the next episode.  The video came through like I was watching it on my HD TV.

If you are a Game of Thrones fan you'll enjoy this season, though if you have certain characters that you favor...you may have to broaden who you favor.  This series is well written, well acted and the costumes and special effects are first rate, you gain an appreciation of characters you may not have liked or considered before, their motives and aspirations.  I don't really care to say much about what happens this season, best you watch it yourself and enjoy it...don't be tempted to skip around, watch it in the order it was meant to be watched.  Overall I think television is usually a waste of time, but series like the Game of Thrones is a refreshing accomplishment and I much prefer to watch a dvd than watch the continuous hype you get between programs from HBO and for the most part cable and network TV is of little interest to me.
Since I don't have HBO I have to wait all year for it to come out. Beyond obsessed with it! Best season yet!

Became hooked on this series from the very first episode and have also read the books..  Although it is a mythical world there are many parallels with medieval times (not including the dragons). All I can say is WOW!!! I have 3 seasons. It has everything a house wife would want. Can hardly wait for the next season. Goin to sit down and watch them all again and a again....Can't even pick a favorite.... Love the good and the very bad..exciting  GET IT  SO GREAT

thought this was the currant season and it is not, do not order to watch if you are going through roku unless you have not seen season 3. so disappointed that season 4 is not out yet as it is currently running on HBO which  do not subscribe to. You cannot get refund on accidental buys!

This item cost ten dollars more at the store. I could probably have found it for this price or waited but much easier to just buy it from Amazon. I like the fact that very few characters move through the entire storyline.  The twist and turns are great.  Also if you kill "The Mother of Dragons" I will write a very stern letter of protest.  Everybody else is open game, good hunting.

There is a lot more action to be had in this season than in previous ones in my opinion.  Mostly in the movement of characters (except one, but he's a turd anyway), but there also seemed to be more fight scenes (which is always fun~).  If you watch it for the sex, it's going down, but if you watch it for plot, there's much to behold.

I can't really add anything to the multitude of 5 star reviews posted here so I'll just say - "I agree".
I don't have HBO so I actually did purchase all three seasons on blu ray and besides the fact that the show is amazing, I've found myself more than once going back to an episode from the season before. There's a huge amount of speaking parts and they keep adding more with each new episode (OK, they eliminate many characters via sword and ax and knife so I guess it may come out even) and with the blu rays from each season they include a little cheat sheet which explains (if you need it) who these new characters are and where they fit into the genealogy of the story so far. And believe me, to follow the genealogy of these families you will need a cheat sheet. If you're offended by bloodshed or nudity or extreme violence (oh Theon, I was jealous of you those first two seasons!) then take a pass. But if you crave some excellent writing and acting, great action sequences, sword fights, lots of blood, sex and nudity, dragons, an epic story, numerous twists and turns and a story that hasn't slowed down once in 30 episode (that I've seen so far), you have to check out GoT!
Each season gets better and better. I don't have HBO GO and I couldn't stop myself from buying each episode one right after the other until I finished the season. Now I need to catch up on season 4.

It's awesome, at first was a little frustrated with new story lines (there's a lot of characters to track) but those story lines have turned out to be quite compelling. concerning the product, one of the dvd's has a wee bit of a skipping issue.
At this point the shows hype speaks for itself. If you're on season 3 you already know how good it is, so support the arts and buy this instead of downloading it.
Best show ever made. If your curious about it then I employe you to give the first 3 episodes a chance. You'll be hooked.

Many interesting characters with very intriguing storyline set in Medieval period. I find the show more entertaining then most series playing on television. I can't wait to see each new episode. Like I said, I look forward to seeing each new episode.

O.K. If you've read a review of mine you know I don't like to give out story just my impression overall of what I saw. With each and every episode you come away with a constant hunger for more. Season three, especially episodes 8, 9, and 10 the season ender trapped my attention completely.  It's complicated and keeps your mind jumping.
This is one of the best series created.  Love this program with the suspense and and alternative reality.  This makes me want to live in a world with magic and ravens.

What more do I have to say.  If you're buying this, you have already seen the first two seasons and are as hooked as I am.  You will hate your eyes by the end, though.  Read the books.
I read these series years ago, i enjoyed it so much i wore out my original copies. The series is just as good, I will probably wear out my original copies of them.
This series is just well written and the plot and story continue to surprise. HBO has just done a phenomenal job on this series.

Purchasing this for a digital download was much cheaper than buying the discs at the store or on bidding sites.  Not my favorite season, it was very short and you could tell they were waiting for the writer to give them more to work with, but, as always, great acting and storyline!

I will keep my comments brief and the reveiw to the physical product rahter than the merits of the show itself.  I think there has been enough debate (with good points on both sides. . . Pro: original story, great acting, gritty realism.  Con: derivitive, excessively gory/sexual, few fantasy elements) as to the quality and validity of GoT.  I have enjoyed the series, and this season was no exception.

The combo DVD, Blu-Ray and digital copy set comes in a nice compact package with a cool plastic slipcover.  The presentation is nice, and the two sets of discs are in separate folders within the box itself.  The Blu-Ray disc folder is much larger than the one for the DVDs, but I like that the separate folders allows for easy lending of one set while you watch the other yourself.

I have not used the digital copy at all yet, and I may never, but I have downloaded digital copy from teh same company previously without any difficulty.

For the price, this set is a wondwerful way to add the Third Season of GoT to your collection.  I do not have HBO, and I have been watching them on disc, so this is going next to the other sets in my video collection.

Chances are that you are not new to GoT if you are looking at the Season Three set, but if you are. . . go back and watch 1 and 2 or you won't know who anybody is or why you should care.

Absolutely excellent story line.  Excellent casting.  I haven't read the books, so I don't know if it is true to the original or not.  Lots of sex and GRAPHIC violence.  Not recommended for children -- or squeamish adults for that matter!  I'm so sorry I don't have HBO, so we can watch Season 4!  (I've already purchased Seasons 1 and 2!)
Seriously awesome season.  Just keeps getting better!  Can't wait to own Season 4. Fabulous acting and each episode keeps you on the edge of your seat!
I give it a thumbs up, my favorite characters are Tyrion & Jon Snow, it is the best game ever!

The books are great, as I've said in my previous review. The series is, so far, leaving a lot to be desired. While it is entertianing it's not living up to all the hype for me.

The characters are not really following or breaking completely away from their stories in the books. Some characters are completely missing (Strong Belwas being the most notable in the third season). All of Dany's handmaidens are dead in the TV series. In the books they are her most loyal and trusted advisors. As such I'm a bit shocked and very sad that the seris is breaking so far away from the books. The third season is the worst about this so far. The Red Lady shows up in Westeros to visit Thoris of Mir and Barrick Dundarian which never happened in the books and as such makes zero sense in the series. It's becoming almost a bit absurd.

I really hope the show can pull together and redeem itself.

Granted you can watch all the episodes if you have HBO GO along with your service provider subscription and save yourself $45. But I personally love to purchase the Blu-Ray sets for the series because each final disc in every season comes with special features that go further in depth into the mythology of its world. It provides background stories and history to characters and their houses, locations and events that are only briefly mentioned in the episodes which may sometimes leave you scratching your head wondering what the characters are even talking about or what it has to do with the setting at hand. All that is further explained in those special features so you never feel lost on who's who and what's what. If you are the kind of viewer who appreciates the show for what it is or just the Fantasy Epic genre in general, I highly recommend you purchase the Blu-Ray sets.

Certainly this season was heartrenching. I did question season 2's departure from the book re Robb and his wife and now I know why. In the book, he broke his oath because of honor and in the show he broke his oath because of love - both leading to the same tragic consequence. I read an opinion piece bemoaning this change, as though the show ruined Robb's character by making his impulsivity emotional rather than about he and his father's shared tragic flaw of being too honorable for the world around them. Oh, but when it came time for the wedding sequence - one cannot deny the power of four-fold doom.

Oh, that scene, that scene! My heart broke seeing the anguish then devastation on Catelyn Stark's face - it has been seared in my mind.

As for other characters - hot dang, I can't believe I now feel sympathy for the person who pushed Bran off the tower. Can anyone evil be redeemed? What Jaime and Theon went through this season was deserved --- and yet it gives me hope that evil can be excised from a person and what is left will only be the good.
