There are a million better reviews out there, so I'm not even going to try, but I'll tell you that if you don't  mind some violence, sex, death, empowered women, dead people coming back to "life", and loads of subplots, you won't be disappointed.

Great Season !!!  Will probably watch several more times.  However I was disappointed in how it was packaged, There was no tabe on either end of the opening and could have fallen out or been removed with ease.

Season three of Game of Thrones has finally won me over.  I tried reading the novels off and on without much success, I wasn't too hooked after season one either... but season two really improved in my opinion.  A lot more intrigue and drama was evenly spaced and made for much better television.

Season three is very interesting because there is a lot going on, but the story moves at a great pace between the main story lines.  I felt the familial issues between the Lannister siblings and pops was very well done and added another little bit of animosity.  The other story lines kept going from where they left off.  I won't add any spoilers, but as in season 2, Daenerys' story continues to awe me.

The pace is more even, the drama isn't too over the top, and the action is intense but not overly silly with cartoonish violence.

All in all it's a great series that continues to get better.  And my oh my, what a wedding we have in store!!!

Although I haven't even viewed any of these episodes, I love this HBO series (but don't subscribe to HBO).  The third season discs arrived in a timely manner and I was billed less than the quoted price which was a nice extra surprise.

I would recommend this to anyone with a sense of adventure, and one who loves gorgeous landscapes, although the battles and other scenes are very graphic, including a lot of nudity and sex, so I wouldn't recommend it to your 10 year old...lol!

i do not have hbo and buy each season when available because the adaptation is so well made.  when traveling on business, i saw a couple of season 1 episodes, which caused me to read the books.  considering how absurd it is that a new release two hour movie costs the same as an entire series like this, i prefer to buy a series.  i hope the directors and martin stay on track.

I liked the first series.  Second series was OK.  Third one ... eh.  HBO needs to hear the message:  move it along, buddy.  All the titties and fannies in the world can't make up for a boring story.  Good acting.  Boring series.  Hopefully next season will be better.

Just finished viewing the 3rd Season - I'm not very politically astute & think of myself as anti-political, so I find the Game of Thrones sortta draggin' on when all I want(ed) is more Dragons - their flying, their fire & burning up tyrants - I feel like I need a book with pages of the characters (w/ pictures) to 'keep up' with the story as I find the intricacy of all the political drama & the intertwining of characters just boring - Loved the 1st Season but not so much the ending - This show seems not to be 'for' the Starks  (I kindda thought they were the 'hero(es)' - The disappointments to the story just never stop - Maybe because I haven't read the Books, which I don't see myself doing, I'm not 'up on' 'wha sup', but I still could use more Dragon stuff.

Oh the drama and intrigue in this series! It is like a Shakespearean Drama mashed up with The Lord of The Rings.  I am not very patiently awaiting the next episodes to be offered on Prime.

I am at odds of how to write this review.
SERIES:
I started watching the series from the start and I very seldomly purchase a TV Season....let alone the entire series.  But I have found this series very entertaining.  There are twist and surprises during this season that makes me look forward to the next season.
DVD/BlueRay:
I am a bit disappointed in the BluRay.  I have found it is very slow in starting.  It seems that the BluRay sits, while it's loading.  I wish there was more though on the BluRay as it should be an immediate load right to the menu.  But it takes several minutes to get to the episode menu.

Third season started off very slow and continued to be very slow until the last 2 episodes. All other episodes in season 3, two many scene jumps and two often. I have the first three seasoned, I hope the fourth season has a bit more action..........I find the idea of Game of Thones, truly great.
Wonderfully congruent story lines, many unexpected twists and turns, shockingly dramatic events and occurrences and many dead main characters.....wow! You had me the whole time. HZ

Awesome series. All three seasons are spectacular. I will watch
them over and over again for years to come. I can't wait for the
next season to come out.
If you like Game of Thrones. go to Oneofus.net and listen to Digital Noise podcast. They review new Blu-rays and DVDs every week.

Just like the third book was by far and away the best in the written series, the 3rd season
of the HBO series is absolutely exceptional. First two seasons I found myself intrigued by some of the storylines, but bored by some of the others. Not the case in the third season, at all. I found myself caring about every second of the show, from the titanic battle between the Starks and Lannisters, to John Snow's daring adventures amongst the Wildlings. I really can't think of one weak performance among any of the characters -- even some of the younger actors like the young man who played Joffrey just hit everything out of the park. Some of the actors are so good they actually improve upon their characters as they were written in the books -- the actor who plays Stannis Baratheon, for example, is just incredible and steals just about every scene he is in; or the actress who plays Ygritte, a very minor character in the books, but here you find you really care about the fate of this character (and her relationship with John Snow); or the actor who plays the impossibly evil Ramsay Snow, totally different from how I pictured him after reading the books (ie. he's small and kind of puny, almost looks like Elijah Wood's evil twin), and yet he is truly terrifying and utterly convincing as a pure and unapologetic sociopath. In short, this is by far and away the best installment in the TV series so far. Will they be able to continue the momentum into season four? If its only half as good as season three it will be absolutely worth watching.
All kinds of pressure now for Martin to finish off books six and seven and really give this outstanding television crew something to work with.
Great this is a great series I enjoyed it very much I would definitely watch season 4 it comes out next year
Great show. Me and husband are huge fans. Wish we had the channel so we could watch the new season when it starts, haha.

So good. So nice. I like so much. All the time real good. So, so good. Thanks wow, real nice.

I'm into my third season.

I still have no idea who half the people are because they all look the same, talk the same, and every other person is king of something. I've got the "Knight's Watch" down, the Blondie with the dragons and her ilk, and King Geoffrey and his "beautiful people".
The rest are just a bunch of dirty buggers, in dirty armor, fighting a war.

Still, for some reason I can't stop watching.

It probably has a lot to do with my love of shows such as "The Tudors", "Borgia: Faith and Fear", and "Rome". I'm a sucker for anything Medieval and before.

Obviously, GOT is fiction... Put me into any period piece and I can draw a frame of reference.

Now, before I get comments about how stupid I am (I'm not), I DO get the overall picture.

Big war, several sides, plenty of cities involved.

All that being said, it is a beautifully scripted show. The acting continues to be outstanding. And the fantasy-end of the show continues to pick up.

If you've already bought seasons I and II, what are you waiting for?
One of my favorite shows and it started off with a bang!!!! Love Jon Snow and Tyrion!!! They make the show for me.

Game of Thrones is one of the few shows I never see when it originally airs, and I always pick up the season Blu-ray. It's becoming a bit of a tradition for me. Fortunately, I am more of a casual viewer of television, but I must admit GOT really intrigued me from the first season. The premise and the notion of high fantasy on the "small screen" is no doubt interesting, but what follows suit is a complex political entanglement. As far as I am concerned, everything is right with this show. The casting is superb across the board, though some actors shine more than others. But, that is the nature of the beast. The third season doesn't seem to have as much momentum as earlier seasons, but it seems to bring more of a conclusion to the Stark family as is really begun in Season 1. The balance between sadness and happiness brought by laughter allows this show to feel very real and human, and thus entertaining. You get addicted to characters then see them removed from the game quickly, to mixed reviews and opinions. The world here feels real.

The actual package is solid enough. I never really care for all the add-ons and what have you, and 30$ was a reasonable price to pay for the 10 episodes of this season on Blu-ray. The DVD for me is just an unnecessary add-on, but I will end up just giving it to a friend.

I put off watching this series as I thought it would be a hokey king/queen show.  Wow, there are so many complicated characters and story lines.  I'm actually sad I finished Seasons 1, 2, and 3 because I want MORE.  I did go back and watch Season 1, now on Season 2.  There are many little things I missed.  Between this, Dexter, Breaking Bad and House of Cards, I don't know which is my favorite.
This is one of my favorite shows. It constantly changes and leaves no end to the saga insight. It will end one day, but I keep wondering who will win.

This series, as fans know, just keeps getting better and better.  This season charts the rise of Daenerys Targaryen, the increasing travails facing the Stark family, Tyrion's navigation of the treacherous climate in King's Landing, the continued unfurling of Jaime and Brienne's journey.  Stannis nurses his wounds while Melisandre plots to make him king of all of Westeros, Arya and Gendry face new foes and unexpected allies, Sansa finds a friend, Joffrey continues his reign of terror, Cersei awaits her beloved, Tywin rules his family with a firm hand, Little Finger and Varys raise the stakes, Theon suffers terrible loss, Jon is kissed by fire and Sam finds his courage.

this show is the best one on t.v  5 stars, should be more like 10. very well made and the story line is...WOW. I will not give it all away.  just don't miss it just got done with the 3 season will be watching all 3 over and over again !!!!!!!!!!!

Five stars for the first season, four stars for the second season, three stars for this season. This story is crying out for some tight editing.

  First of all I'd drop the Bran story. That kid has been wondering around the woods looking at three eyed crows for the last season and a half. He hasn't really contributed to the plot since he got thrown out of a tower in the first episode. Next to go is Theon Greyjoy. We spent all of season three watching this guy get tortured. Why? And finally I'd drop Stanis Baratheon and the red witch. Should of snuffed this guy at the battle for Kings Landing. Instead we get an entire season of him licking his wounds. None of these people spoke a single word to any of the story's main characters for the entire thrid season.

  In my opinion there are four great stories here and we should stick with them. Aria's story is great. The Kings Landing stuff is the meat of the story. Jon Snow's adventures beyond the wall, terrific. Daenerys Targaryen's story, great. Everytime we move away from one of those four stories the show comes to a grinding halt while we wait to get back to the characters we care about.

  Less would be more in season four.

Game of Thrones is probably my favorite television series.  When it first premiered, I was intrigued, but I had trouble following along because of all the characters. I gave it a second chance when HBO ran a Season 1 marathon before the start of Season 2, and that time, I was immediately hooked.  I have now seen all three seasons of the HBO show, and I am very excited about Season 4, which premieres in April.

Season 3 of Game of Thrones covers the first half of Storm of Swords, which is the third book in George R.R. Martins A Song of Ice and Fire series.  The biggest theme in Season 3 is that of change; alliances change constantly, nothing can be predicted, and no one is safe.  The Battle of Blackwater, which ended Season 2, was certainly a turning point in the War of Five Kings, but the war is far from over.  Stannis Baratheon has retreated to his castle at Dragonstone, and is planning his next move with Melisandre, the Red Priestess.

Back in Kings Landing, Joffrey Baratheon continues his career as king of the realm/psychotic teenager.  He has broken his engagement to Sansa Stark, and agreed to marry Margaery Tyrell because of the Tyrells role in saving Kings Landing during the Battle of Blackwater.  Sansa remains a hostage in the court, unsure of her future, but grateful for Margaerys friendship.

Jamie Lannister, who was taken prisoner by the Starks, has been set free by Catelyn Stark.  He is to be escorted to Kings Landing by the warrior maid Brienne of Tarth, where he is to be exchanged for Sansa and Arya Stark.  Jamie and Brienne have some great chemistry, and I really enjoyed their scenes together.

Unbeknownst to them, Arya Stark is not in Kings Landing.  She has been out on the road since the very end of Season 1.  She has managed to escape from Harenhall with her friends Gendry and Hot Pie.  But the roads are not a safe place for two teenage boys and a girl, even if that girl is as feisty as Arya.  Eventually, Arya acquires a very unlikely partner in crime.  To reveal the identity of her cohort would be a spoiler, but I will say that I would watch a spinoff of these two characters all day long.

Robb Stark finds himself in a precarious position.  His mothers actions cost him some key allies, and he must approach Walder Frey for assistance in regrouping and preparing his next step towards winning the war.  Theres just one problem: Robb was supposed to have married one of Walder Freys daughters, but he married someone else instead.  Is Walder a forgiving man?

Jon Snow has infiltrated the Wilding camp beyond the wall, and met their king, Mance Rayder.  He finds himself captivated by a Wilding woman named Ygritte, but will falling in love distract him from his mission?

Across the narrow sea, Daenerys Targaryen strives to build the army that she needs to conquer Westeros.  She does not have very much gold, but she does have her three dragons.  Will that be enough?

One of my favorite things about this season is the music, especially the showrunners choice to make The Rains of Castamere, the Lannister family song be played or mentioned repeatedly this season.  Cersei and Margaery even have a conversation about the song, and then it is played in the most pivotal scene in the entire season.  It is just such a delightful bit of foreshadowing.  Another aspect of the music that I liked was the music that played over the credits at the end of each episode.  It was different every time, and the choices are just fraught with symbolism.

The acting is phenomenal.  No one, in my opinion, was a weak link.  I was particularly impressed by the teenage actors/actresses, who do such fine work with difficult material.  King Joffrey, in particular, brought psychotic behavior to a new level.  He swaggers about during the day bullying people and sneering, but his dark tastes come out at night.  He considers himself to be very important, and it is very satisfying to see Tywin Lannister, his maternal grandfather, reduce him to a petulant child.

One of my favorite scenes involves Joffrey with Margaery Tyrell.  Margaery has gotten intel from Sansa regarding Joffrey, and she feigns interest in his crossbow.  He is just thrilled to pieces when she asks if she can touch it.  Oh, the symbolism!

My favorite new character had to be Olenna Tully, Margaerys grandmother, and the matriarch of the Tully family.  Without a doubt, she is the Dowager Countess of Westeros because she always has a sharp word for those who deserve it, but she treats Sansa Stark with kindness and dignity.

Game of Thrones is not for everyone.  The language, violence, and sexual situations are all explicit.  This show is rated TV-MA, which is the equivalent of an R rating.  It is intended for an adult audience.  If I had one negative thing to say about the show it would be that the torture of one particular character went on for far too long and was beginning to resemble torture porn.  Enough already!

The Season 3 box set includes all sorts of extras.  I have been watching the digital copy, which imports directly to iTunes where I can watch via our AppleTV.  I have not yet had a chance to listen to any of the audio commentaries, but I did watch several of the special features, which provide insight into the making of the show.

I would absolutely recommend Game of Thrones Season 3.  The plot builds upon the storylines established in the previous seasons, and there are many surprises.  The acting is phenomenal, the scenery is breathtaking, the costumes are gorgeous everything about Game of Thrones is amazing.  If you have not seen the previous seasons, they are available to HBO subscribers at no cost via the HBO Go app.  Season 3 is also available via HBO Go, but I picked up my own copy so that I could have the audio commentaries and digital copy.  Now that I have rewatched Season 3, I cant wait for Season 4- its going to be a good one!

There are too many uncritical 5 star reviews for this season so I have to chime in.  Just because it's Game of Thrones doesn't earn it an automatic 5 stars. This is mostly just a filler season.  Last year it was interesting to see Cersei show an almost sympathetic side for a minute or two, so this year they try to generate some sympathy for Jamie Lannister and Theon Greyjoy.  Two worthless characters that we hate and rightly so. There can be no redemption for them.  They are bad guys, plain and simple. What's next, sympathy for Joffrey?  I'm sorry, no.  And that's about half of the entire season right there spent on these two non-interesting characters.  Then there's the one thing that really happens that seems random and capricious and desperate on the part of the storytellers. I can just hear them in the writers room: "We have to do SOMEthing this year!?" The rest of the characters just go around in circles and nothing really happens for them.  Even the opening theme music seems to be less impressive this season, like they re-recorded it with sparser instrumentation or something to underscore that we're just passing time this season and not really doing anything.  Maybe just my imagination.  But there is no excuse for turning in a half-baked season with 80 percent filler.  I waited a whole year for these ten hours and now I'm just waiting again for another year.  Another season like this and GOT will have officially jumped the dragon!

I watched this entire season already before the Blu-Ray came out, but I still pre-ordered this immediately for a few reasons

1.) I like buying and promoting things that I love. (Money goes toward the company to keep them making these things, as well as adds to the numbers for the success rating, la la la)

2.) I like to re-watch, obviously, and blu-ray is beautiful

3.) The extra features. They are amazing. More on that right now:

The extra features, so far the only one I have watched was the one on the Red Wedding episode, where they pretty much go through the entire episode scene by scene and talk about it: The production, the reasoning behind things, and even the difference between the book and the show. The author of the books (and creator of this universe as a whole) is also there and is interviewed, as well as the shows producers, set designers, and of course, actors.

Additionally, every episode features commentary, but who is the commentary by? Different people every time! And no, not the producers, but the actors! It's MULTIPLE different actors for different episodes. Some episodes have Sam and Gilly, some have Jon Snow, Ygritte. Some have Daenerys, etc etc. Even Theon's torturer is there.

With amazon (currently) selling this set for only 29.99, there's absolutely no reason to buy this; this bundle is a steal of a deal at 29.99

Buy, Support, Enjoy.

I got this version (Game of Thrones: The Complete Third Season (Blu-ray/DVD Combo + Digital Copy) (2014)) because I figured we'll get a Blu-ray player next time we get an optical reader/player to go with the TV. But right now we have only a regular DVD player. This set consists of 7 (seven) discs - 5 Blu-ray and 2 conventional DVD. The DVDs are double sided, labeled in very small print, and ONLY contain the 10 (ten) episodes of season 3 of HBO's Game of Thrones.

Beware! NONE of the "Special Features" described in this product's description are available on the standard DVDs!

There are NO commentaries by actors, writers, directors, producers. There are NO extra deleted scenes, extra scenes, director's cuts, or anything else. There are NO comments by costumers, armorers, combat coaches, or dragon wranglers! There are no "making of", "behind the scenes", locations commentaries, or any other such features. There is NOTHING - EXTRA - AT - ALL in standard DVD!!!!!!!!!

I totally didn't understand this when I ordered this set & will be returning the set ASAP.

The show is fantastic, with Season 3 the best yet. Can't watch them on my just arrived Blu-rays, however!

While I can't penalize the rating of the show for the issues I have with the Blu-rays (hence the 5 stars), a warning about possible defects with this season's discs may be warranted. The first 3 discs will not play on my current model year Sony Blu-ray player that has its firmware updated. The Sony main menu screen never disappears and the discs just spin and rev for a couple of minutes before I get an error message that the discs cannot be read. As the last two discs DO play (the "godswood tree" does appear with those, and fairly quickly) it would appear that the first 3 discs are faulty. None of the disks show any scratches or damage that I can detect. In any case, it does seem odd that more than one disc would be faulty. Hopefully more light can be shed on this by other reviewers, as I see other customer reviews that indicate similar problems with this season's Blu-rays.

As they have superb customer service with an easy exchange process, Amazon is sending out a new set and I hope that this does the trick. If not, then I need to find out how this can be escalated to HBO.

Curious if HBO manufactured a bad batch of discs? If so, I hope Amazon works with HBO expediently to ensure that no more of them get out to their customers.

Show is awesome, and this season is no exception.  With that being said, this review will primarily focus on the quality of the Blu-ray presentation and physical packaging.

  [Minor Spoilers Ahead]

PQ: The episodes contained within these disks are ridiculously gorgeous plain and simple.  If you thought the broadcast versions (or pirated 720p ones) were good looking just wait until you see the blu-ray video quality.  The lighting is absolutely fantastic, in particular some of the darker scenes are absolutely amazing (especially the ones using fire as the main light source).  Speaking of dark scenes there are quite a few of them this season, and luckily the black levels are spot on.  As with previous seasons the locations shot on this show are some of the most beautiful you will ever see, and will look stunning on your big TV.  The sets and costumes have always looked amazing on Game of Thrones, but this season they really outdid themselves.  Not that it needs to be said but the use of GC is excellent this season, nothing new here

Some scenes to showcase picture quality
-Anything involving the wall
-Beric vs. Clegane
-Dannys parley with Yunkai
-Garden scenes in kings landing
-Anything in Geoffrys/Cercies/Tyrions chambers

AQ: My god this is an impressive DTS-HD MA 5.1 soundtrack.  Hard to say if it's better than the previous two seasons, but I do think that season 3 had more chances to fully utilize what a modern home theater system can produce.  Excellent use of surrounds and LFE channel.  Most importantly the dialog is always given a priority in the mixing which makes it very clear and easy to understand.  Top it all off with the incredible soundtrack (gotta love Rains of Castamere) and you have something very incredible indeed.

Some scenes to showcase audio quality
-Climbing the Wall
-Summer snarling at Jojen
-Beric vs. Clegane
-Most Dragon scenes
-Sam and Gilly at the weirwood

Packaging:  Pretty much the same as previous two seasons.  Case is white instead of black and the slip cover is made of plastic.  I like this because my cardboard covers always get frayed around the corners after extended use.  DVD copies look like they might be hard to remove from there sleeve without scratching, but I haven't tried myself.

As a final note the extras are phenomenal for season 3. My favorites are:
-Making of "The Rains of Castamere"
-Histories and lore
-Deleted scene: Tywin and Pycelle

Okay, remember the scene from the original HBO broadcast where Theon Greyjoy is being tortured, and he's brought down from the torture rack and temporally seduced by several women? Shortly afterwards his tormentors come back in and cut off his manhood. Remember that? That scene is missing from the Blu Ray edition that I just finished watching. So I'm not sure what's going on with this blu ray, but that scene has been edited out!

A pirated DVD would probably have loaded a lot faster.  There is so much nonsense on the DVDs that it begs the patience of a saint.

Will not play on PS3. Completely updated system will not even register there is a disc inserted. I love the show, 5 stars for the show, but the formatting here is atrocious. Would not even run on my custom built computer (less than 1 year old) until I -bought- a brand new piece of software. No free programs have kept up with this. DRM is going too far here.  I am all for protecting copyright, but if I paid for it and still can't watch it with the hardware that worked just last month, I'm going to get pissed.

Glad I got it working at all, as I have been waiting and waiting to watch this season.

I have to take a star off for the packaging. Just because a combo pack offers 3 ways of viewing the content doesn't mean it can skimp on one of those ways (and the one most likely to actually be used).

The DVDs came in a cardboard sleeve, stuck to it with an adhesive that gummed up the disks, meaning that while playing the second side of both of them I encountered damaged areas I was forced to skip past. The minutes lost amounted to around 6 or 7 total, which is an eternity in a show this intricate.

Not to mention the fact that I've been waiting with excitement for a year to watch this. I don't have HBO, I wanted to get it through legitimate channels and I was patient until it came out on DVD. I shouldn't have the experience marred by issues with brand new DVDs.

So kudos to the creators of the show and all the cast and crew involved. It was as epic as I expected it to be, and I could honestly not praise it higher. But for the love of the seven gods use some common sense on your packaging.

Waiting a whole year for my Game of Thrones is always pretty rough. I've read all the books and re-watch the previous seasons throughout the year to hold me over as I do not have HBO. When the new seasons are released, it's very difficult to avoid binge-watching marathons! This is the greatest masterpiece on television, and is so much better than most theatre-released movies that I would compare it to epic films such as my favorite Lord of the Rings trilogy and Hobbit films. Each episode leaves you itching for more, it's just pure escapism and has the greatest characters. I just got my Blu-ray season 3 and began watching today. It's the first season I own on Blu-Ray and it's exquisite. The discs are acting a bit strange, taking a long time to load and the second disc wouldn't start, but after I turned the player off and on again it worked. Hopefully this is not enough to have to warrant an exchange, but just an issue I found worth mentioning. There's tons of special features I haven't even begun to watch yet, but the price for the collection is amazing and I'm so thrilled to have brand new shows again that I know I will enjoy forever. If you love fantasy like I do, it doesn't get better than this.

The acting and dialogue are on a different level this season especially with Tywin Lannister, Charles Dance OWNS this season along with lots of great new characters with some familiar faces if you've seen films like There Will Be Blood, the remake of The Thing, The Dark Knight Rises, Pacific Rim, or Richard Ayoade's (The IT Crowd, The Watch) film Submarine. This season also gets better special effects with the growing dragons and a sword fight that looks like something from a Star Wars movie. You can't miss with this season, too good. Season four has a lot to live up to. As far as the books go I'm only halfway through A Clash of Kings, the second book, but it seems like there are elements still from that book in this season, Bran Stark's scenes in particular, so I don't think the seasons match up with the book number. To put it bluntly, the fundamental problem of the books and the video is the extraordinary fragmentation of the story.  There are far too many characters and far too many events in the story, characters dying almost arbitrarily and new characters being introduced almost andomly, to keep track of any presumption of a story line.  Seriously, as much as I love the various characters in the story, their deaths/rebirths/introductions as new characters in the plot, could drive any person with even a genius IQ absolutely nuts...

Anyone trying to follow the plot MUST - absolutely MUST - read both the books and watch the HBO translation of the books into video.  No disrespect to George R.R. Martin, as an author myself who understands the difficulties he faces in writing this story, the story is GROSSLY fragmented... primarily because the story is about the GAME OF THRONES, not about any character or group of characters, and that does not come out very strongly in the written story... and largely because - I suspect - some idiot MBAs somewhere are pushing the author to stretch the story out beyond anything reasonable (I've dealt personally with idiot MBAs running publishing shops, so my sympathies extend to George R.R. Martin).

I have to give credit to the producers and writers for HBO; it is extraordinary how they've translated the books into video.  I (personally) could listen all day to the musical score, and I find the story line ( in video) to be astounding, although he way the jump from event to event would drive me nuts if I hadn't also read the books.

I do not, however, find the books' story line to be anywere as enthralling as the video...  As a writer myself (under a pseudonym),  I understand George R. R. Martin's difficulty in  handling so many different  characters dispersed across so may different areas in the story (he personally makes note of the problems himself in Book 2 and at the end of Book 4), but rationalizations for a problem do not eliminate the problem.  I give  him credit for acknowledging the difficulty...  Personally, I  think he should have made much more emphasis of the fact that the story is about the GAME OF THRONES, not about individual characters or familes of characters...

I'm not going to tap dance around this too much; I enjoy the videos much more than the books... but I have allready read the books before I have ever looked at the videos.  I don't think they are capable of standing alone... I susect people who only read the books or only see the videos are left confused.

It is unfortunate; in combination, it is an extraorinary story... and poor George R.R. Martin must be going insane trying to keep everything straight...  There are just so many characters and so many subplots...

The actors are magnificent; the show's writers are magnificent... without them, the books fall flat.
  Without the books, the videos fall flat...

Hello Amazon,

Note: This review pertains only to the limited edition bonus mantel, not to the actual television series.

Amazon has certainly posted a hyped-up review of this limited edition bonus mantel, and I almost turned into the "Mad King" Aerys II Targaryen while waiting for it to arrive on my doorstep. The packaging fed into my hysteria, unfortunately, as it arrived in a ridiculously over-sized box, which contained the smaller box that housed the actual item. After ravaging the packaging with tooth and claw, I couldn't have been more disappointed with the actual mantel, which drove me into a double madness and led to the review you see before you.

Amazon informs you that the mantel is "created in durable heavy weight material," is "highly textured," and is "finished with a weathered look evoking the feel of Westeros and a bygone era." Yes, the "bygone era" of sound craftsmanship - not of Westeros. The "durable heavy weight material," while looking sleek from a great distance, is cheap plastic and not "heavy weight material" whatsoever. Although the wings of the dragon are done well, albeit extremely fragile, the dragon's face, upon closer inspection, is completely lacking in texture and rather looks like a kindergarten Play-Doh project. With my mantel, the eyes are lacking any coloring (which gives the impression that this dragon is eyeless), and there are two or thee randomly placed teeth jutting uncannily from its mouth. Even worse is the fact that the Game of Thrones logo seems hurriedly painted (and smudged) in more than one place.

If you "make room on your mantel for this one-of-a-kind packaging" a small breeze, let alone a strong wind of winter, will knock the top off of the base, as the hidden compartment which houses the complete third season has no locking mechanism for the base/mantel whatsoever.

"With a wink to fans, the back is engraved with "Dracarys", a word from the Valyrian language playing homage to wildfires and dragons." That wink is all you will receive in terms of "homage," unfortunately, unless you are a diehard collector of Game of Thrones collectibles. To be fair, it is quite difficult to justify an additional $60.00 for this mantel over the cost of the standard Blu-ray/DVD/Digital edition.

Although I highly doubt G.R.R. Martin would be pleased with this product, the best part of this limited edition is, of course, the enchanting television program. I hope this review helps fans seeking the bonus. Game on!

Okay, yes, this was my favorite season. Tyrion and Bronn are in fine form, Daenerys starts to show her strengths, Arya and the Hound galavant around the Riverlands, and Jaime and Brienne have some very fine moments together. Which is to say nothing of the Red Wedding, one of the greatest treatments of any scene from the book so far.

BUT, this is also my favorite box set. The slipcover with the semi-opaque dragon on it is a nice touch, and once again we get the DVD, Blu-Ray, and digital download. Amazon also lowered the price to $29.99, which makes this set an incredible value. The featurettes are also a nice inclusion, although they are nothing particularly earth-shattering if you kept up with extras on HBO's on-demand service. Still, this is a good treatment for the series' best-yet season. And at less than $30, it's a heck of a deal.

The drama is high, the violence brutal, and the lust on display in every episode of Game of Thrones. Excellent series that captured my attention and will retain it for the fourth and subsequent seasons.
Amazing sets .... fascinating characters ... masterful acting .... it's  an all-encompassing journey to a fabled, magical world just by turning on your tv!

First of all its a great show. I've read the books (book 3, on which this season was based, was absolutely superb, one of the best books I've ever read actually) but I think this would be very good indeed even if you had not read the books?

The dvd extras are very good - I particularly enjoyed the commentary of Richard Madden (Robb) & Michelle Fairly (Catelyn)'s on the Rains episode. Nice to have a few extended/deleted scenes, particularly one with Jon meeting Mance Rayder; another with Tywin meeting up with Pycelle isn't much cop, can see why they left that out; Tywin is best sparring with his son

The 15 minute video synopsis of the previous season is very VERY useful as there really is so much going on. A close watcher of the show might not remember that Bran & Rickon are presumed dead, that Littlefinger misled Catelyn into thinking BOTH her daughters were still held at Kings Landing

Actually, it might be a good idea, if you have NOT read the books to watch the previous seasons, to get you up to speed.

Nice touches: Ned being mentioned in the penultimate episode of the season. Its easy to forget how important his character was to the show, and how all the chaos unfolding is out of his unfair treatment by Joffrey back in season 1

Minor characters (like Roose Bolton, introduced in season 2) become crucial to the plot, and the attention to detail is crucial, especially if you've read the books. And that's another thing - the show is clearly done by fans of the book. There are no major changes to the book. Robb's wife gets a name change, and Arya meets with Tywin back in season 2 (as did NOT happen in the books) but theres nothing major. The author (Martin) writes for the show for an episode a season, and its clear that the show is following the book very closely. (Martin has a commentary on his Bear & the Maiden Fair also)

The casting: spot on. Mance is as you remember him from the book. Hey! I LIKE the guy

In my opinion, the book helps if you watch the show, filling everything out (as it were) so you might want to pick them up at some point

But the show is a can't miss, really. Season 3 is absolutely superb, winter is coming. Not near enough of the White Walkers as you could wish, but the threat is there. Can't wait to see season 4 and Tyrion getting a bit of his own back against his father!

(Season 4 will be based on book 3 also. Its a massive book but well worth the read. You might want to pick it up if you want to swim in it for a while!
Such a rivoting story. I love the action and excitement. I can't wait to read the books and compare. I know I'll love them.

WARNING* SPOILER ALERTS- Okay, I've already read the books GAME of THRONES... Twice...And the people of Britan have been perusing the material on this video all year, so please forgive me as I comment on things that some people might not know about. Like the guy on the news lately that was lost at sea for a year. He will definitely be shocked! But the story is just so huge I can't really imagine someone whom hasn't at least a clue as to the forthcoming horror/shock! AND several (such as myself) whom are still in denial. It can't be true; The Red Wedding..every body dies!?!? It still blows my mind! I find myself lost in this magical Kingdom that George R.R.Martin has created every time I watch or read the story as it goes along. I feel as if I belong there! I want to fight with Robb, I wanted to behead Walder Frey! I'm still shocked over my own inner viciousness about that. I wanted to walk the wall with John Snow (whom I surmise will be king of all Westeros in the end)....is that love blossoming between The king slayer Jamie, and his lady (warden/defender) night Briann?  And I want to personally choke King Joffrey. And I wanted to be the one to push Lysa Arryn out of the Eyrie! And toss her weird mammary fixated brat out immediately after! That's right! I said it! And you all know that you did too! Don't lie! Lol. And I was completely convinced that when Eddard Stark was beheaded (in the very first season no less!!) That the story would quickly  become unraveled. I thought Martin completely MAD! And then, he kills off half the main catchers!! I thought that was surely the end and the story would Peter out. The shocking ending to this third book is just unbelievable! But the story keeps going, and growing, and spreading! It's like nothing I've ever read before. And I can't wait for the next Book that's coming out?!What about Arya!? Does she become an assassin!? What about Sansa and Little finger!?  When is Daenerys Targaryen and her Dragons going to set this Game of Thrones on fire!? And when/how is Tyrions' voyage going to be put in there?
  Ahhh. But we'll all have to wait for those answers.
  I absolutely can't wait to see how Martin brings all this together in the next book! Now that I have vented, here is the serious truth...
  I honestly believe that this series is one of the most intricate, and exciting story's of our time.
  NOTE* I've had this video pre-ordered for months! And Amazon got it to my door within 48 hours of the release!!
I didn't get to see it on cable and so I've got the whole series!  I can't wait for the next one!

This rating and comment is for the limited edition "sculpture" and not for the series.

I was so excited to see this exclusive limited edition set on Amazon. I couldn't wait to open it and add this to my shelf. It says in the description "Created in durable heavy weight material". It is not or I got the wrong thing. It looks just like the picture but it feels like cheap flimsy plastic. It doesn't connect into the base to give it some stability. If you aren't extremely careful it will fall off the base. I've tried to "lock it in place" but there isn't any way to do so, and I'm afraid that if I push too hard it will break in my hands. Alot of money for plastic. Also, the "hidden compartment" was almost impossible to get the movies out of. It's a very tight fit and I thought maybe with the movies in the statue part it will connect to the base better. Nope it doesn't. The prongs on the statue that fit into the base are also very flimsy and feel like they can easily be broken off. They really don't do any good anyway since they don't hold the pieces tightly together. If they are going to make something like this then it should connect together tightly. The slightest movement can send the statue part off the base and onto the floor.

5 stars for the series. 1 star for the "sculpture".

The day of the release my ups guy dropped it off and normally I would have just put this on the shelf and be done with it until just before the next series starts and I marathon through it. I opened the box and found that although the box was in great condition and all my blue ray disks were fine my normal DVD set that my third world friends who can't be bothered to buy a blue ray player normally use was scratched. I called customer service and spoke to a very friendly customer service rep who ordered me a replacement, emailed me a conformation,  upgraded shipping and gave me free return shipping, all without me asking. I work for a bank who prides it's self on its customer service but we could learn a thing from Amazon. I had heard of the service being great but was not expecting that. Thank you Amazon and anyone who buys this do not be put off about the potential of it being scratched because of my review. Amazon offers a great product at a super low price.

I am so confused by some of the reviews that seem to suggest that this season was just "meh." What show were you watching!? If you complain about it not being faithful enough to the books...I challenge you to do a better job writing a script, these books are damn near unfilmable because of the size, scope, and huge cast of characters. It is not the books, it is a television adaption, and a damn fine one at that. Now if you are complaining about the Red Wedding...seriously, grow a pair. The point of this show is to feel gritty, real, and unpredictable. If you didn't like that twist, why are you watching GoT in the first place? This show will kick you in the nuts, and keep kicking you while you're down, but that's what makes the triumphant moments so rewarding. Now, with that out of the way: Excellent season, great character arcs, (Jaimie, Robb, Jon Snow, and Daenerys' were my personal favorites) and some truly epic moments. Seeing Khaleesi grow as a leader was awesome (and THE DRAGONS. The dragons look better than most major Hollywood CGI creations), and the romance between Jon and Ygritte was so good! Jaime is brilliantly complex. And Robb's story...well just you wait. Overall, continues the epic (but for adults only) saga of blood, sex, betrayal, love, and politics. PLEASE FINISH THIS ONE GOOD GRRM, you are so close to pulling off one of the greatest fantasy sagas of all time. I have faith in HBO, but they need the books on time!

Nobody like HBO knows how to bring a series with cinematic quality. The script is marvelous and the actors brilliant. Game of thrones promises more than it can deliver in the aspect of visuals. It is still imprisoned in a tv-budget after all. My other major point is the adult content. The sexual scenes are distracting, gratuitous and unnecessary. At a time when anyone seeking porn can watch it free on the internet, why a tv show keeps devoting time to sexual explicit scenes? The perverts already have plenty of means to satisfy their impulses away from paid cable... so lets focus on the drama and the characters, please! Speaking of the various plots of the series, I particularly enjoy those taking place in Westeros, and specially the North. But Dany's story is the most feeble. While the medieval scenario of Westeros is credible and grounded on reality, the oriental-magical nature of Essos looks cheap and childish.

When it comes to premium cable, my worlds shift as the year goes on. For thirteen weeks in the fall, I get Showtime to watch HOMELAND and one of the best new shows on cable, MASTERS OF SEX. But for the rest of the year, I go back to HBO, and while there are many other good and compelling shows on that channel, such as THE NEWSROOM, and less so, TRUE BLOOD, the main reason I keep coming back is for GAME OF THRONES. And Season Three was perhaps the ultimate lesson as to why this show keeps you coming back. I've reviewed all of the seasons here, and while I found the first season a little problematic but really good overall, the second season was even better, and it just keeps improving into this season.

It's hard to distill everything that happens in this season, and all the new characters and threats that are introduced, so I'll try to distill it in what I believe are the best moments. Daenerys Targaryen meeting The Unsullied, and her trek in defiance of a "man's world" is so vital, so strong and never gets stale. Bran meeting Jojen Reed to make sense of what he's becoming as a warg starts slow but builds extremely well. Jon Snow and Ygritte's relationship and Jon's "undercover" work with Mance Rayder's men is always compelling and suspenseful. The conflict that comes to a head between the Night's Watch and Craster. The initially antagonistic relationship between Jaime and Brienne comes into sharper focus as they warm up to each other. The plight of Davos and his friendship with Stannis conflicting with the intentions of Melisandre. The wedding of Tyrion and Sansa and the rift that creates with Shae. The interminable cruelty of Joffrey, and how he keeps getting figuratively spanked by Tywin. The Brotherhood Without Banners and the firey combat between The Hound and Beric. The women of the Tyrell family, particularly Olenna. The bear pit. The end of Astapor.

And then, of course, The Red Wedding.

I know that of everything that has happened in this season, the most talked-about event is the Red Wedding, and while there are many other important things happening, the episode "The Rains of Castamere" is a horrific, tragic and emotionally devastating event that, for people who are merely fans of the show and not of George R.R. Martin's epic novels like myself, seemed to come out of nowhere, but going back, you can see it coming with hindsight. It firmly establishes the brutally pragmatic machinations of Twyin and his exploitation of the personal slights felt by Roose Bolton and Walder Frey. Although, while the twists and turns of the Lannisters prove to have the most meat on them, the heart of the season stands firmly with Daenerys. She proves to be not only a brilliant strategist, but a leader that could rule with a merciful and generous heart. The soul of the show belongs to Jon Snow, a young man so clearly over his head in a situation that will force him to question his loyalties and his oath to the Night's Watch, making him the stand-in for the audience.

As usual, everyone in the show is pretty amazing, but most surprising of all is the turn from Nikolaj Coster-Waldau as Jaime Lannister. It took a while for the audience to connect with him, particularly when his first significant deed of the show was to push Bran out of a window. But this season, more layers of the onion are peeled back to show that there is much more to him than what we've seen before, which makes me very happy since his was the character that I couldn't get with at all for quite some time. Emilia Clarke continues to amaze with her performance as the Mother of Dragons, and Charles Dance totally owns you (and everyone else around him) as Tywin Lannister. Wisely, the show decided to show much more of what was going on around the kingdoms, and not to devote too much focus to the conflict between the Starks and Lannisters.

So bring on the White Walkers. Winter is coming and I'm ready.

At least, I hope I'm ready.

I think that some people are confused about the pricing...  The list price for the regular edition (Blu-ray/DVD/Digital Copy) - not the limited edition - is actually the same as Seasons 1 & 2.  The discounted price for the first two seasons compared to the 3rd season is typical of most tv shows when there is an upcoming release...  If you want the limited edition, you'll pay more, but you can still get the regular edition for a reasonable cost.
As for the actual show, I have the 1st and 2nd seasons, and love how they were done.  I have not seen the 3rd season; I've only read the books, so I can't say much about it just yet.  I'm looking forward to it, but not looking forward to it, if you know what I mean...  So my star rating doesn't really apply, I suppose, but I thought I'd bring it up.

I've gotten some of the Walking Dead Limited Ed Special packages....but this dragon is pretty underwhelming from the photo. Is there going to be anything better out there? Also, since it's a "limited" edition, I'd love to know HOW LIMITED. They aren't numbered...so will they just print to order...or does someone know how many of these will be produced. Who produced the mold for this packaging? At least the folks who do the Walking Dead releases have told us that it's done by Todd McFarland's toy company, which has pretty high standards in my experience. I hate paying a premium for this realease and then finding there is a nicer Limited Edtion exclusive produced by Best Buy or Target! So many of seem so much better connected than I am about these things! Is there some internet group that deals with these topics? Thanks for any information you can share!

spoiler alert
Most stories have a beginning, a middle and an end, but I get the sense that this story will never end.  I have read that at its current pace show will pass the books by season 6 or season 7, if that happens the show will continue on its own until it reaches the conclusion of the story.  Seven seasons is a very long time let alone going beyond that.

I have watched all 30 episodes over the past couple of weeks, a great way to watch a series in my opinion. I've never been one for watching a series of this type week by week, but to get to the conclusion I guess I will have to start or wait several years for it to finish.

It has been an entertaining show thus far, I find many of the characters interesting and some have redeeming qualities but most of those characters are now dead. At first the shock value of killing off many of the characters that have any compassion or decency was intriguing, but now seems more like a cheap writers ploy to rid the story of an abundance of story lines.

The cinematography and most of the acting, is done quite well but it could have been done just as well without all the gratuitous sex and violence. Dismemberment, rape, murder, incest, human sacrifice, torture, gay sex,  all seem forced and not altogether necessary.  All and all a good show. Can't wait to see which characters I enjoy get killed next.

HBO made it too commercial, too porney, and too divergent from the book.  Moments lost, clarity askew, and higher purpose forgotten.  There are a few excellent performances, maybe one that is exemplary.  Consequences are present (should not a good man behaving foolishly suffer the fate of a fool) and one's family is frequently not a source of deep wisdom.  Hard lessons, in a hard world where there is little comfort from faith, only advantage.  It is worth a watch just to see that the privilege of power is not free and that at times the cost is the iron price.

I've never been that into medieval type shows/movies. But I've had a change of heart.. I love this show. This season is the best one yet! Omg.. the writers have gone crazy! I COULD NOT  believe that wedding. I still can't believe they did that! wtf That definitely had everyone talking. If you haven't given this show a chance in the past you'll for sure want to know what the heck I'm talkin about. So, purchase it. But start with s1. so good!

I have read the books and watched the shows and I have to say that I love both! The books are excellent because of the great detail and character development. The show takes the books and makes them into small movies each week! The third season of Game of Thrones mirrors the third book in the series. However this season only covers approximately half of the 3rd book. For the book readers this is up to the "Red Wedding", I do not want to say anything more to spoil any of the story!

The actors in this show really stay pretty close to those in the book, I am really impressed with the casting! I personally cannot wait to get this and see all the extra features that will be included!

I definitely recommend this collection, it certainty lives up to the quality expected from HBO!

There are so many feelings to express that I do not have enought words to words the sadness and pain that is felt for the people who lived in the flea bottom.  I felt so much sadness for the Starks and hatred for Frey.  I do hope the writer has something terrible for Waldo.  Tyrion has turned out to be kind and Bron as his watchman is also great as he lends some humor.  Do not let Jon Snow die as is indicated in the book as he was stabbed by his companions.
If you like the books, you'll LOVE this beginning of the story played out. - The sets and characters are wonderful. It seems the book has come to life.

Continues to be riviting entertainment to say the least although the last episode moves a little slower than episodes that precede it.  However almost every episode preceding the last one pretty much left me reeling.
What a sad state of affairs it is when the DVD hasn't even been released yet and there are 21 "reviews".  Most are anticipating how great the series will be when it's finally released.  Geez...

This is just a placeholder for Season 3. Now that it's done, once HBO releases specifications for it, we'll get something more concrete with better pricing.

Since they introduced HBO Select (Blu-Ray, DVD, and Digital formats in a single package) earlier last year and began embracing it with some of their recent releases, including Game of Thrones (both Seasons 1 and 2), it's certain that when Season 3 is officially given specifications and pricing, we'll know what we are getting.

Until then, I'm going to wait. But it will be worth it.

This show really turned me off after episode 29 with the wedding massacre.  I don't care if it was in the book or not, it was horrifying.  The producers made other changes from the book so they could have changed this too.  I don't want to spoil it by telling you what happens, but as a woman I am offended by the sheer brutality that this show seems to have embraced.  I'm sure all the men will find this review unhelpful but I don't care. I speak my mind!

The casting of characters and their interactions in this medieval fantasy story are captivating with many pearls of wisdom that can be applied to the realities of today. I love everything about it and have watched all of the DVDs in this series several times, seeing something new each time.

The paperback book costs $7.99. Where is the logic and sense of charging close to $100 for the visual equivalent? The usual cost of a bluray film is $19.00 or thereabouts. This is obviously an attempt to extort money from people. Although I do not usually give reviews based on cost I feel this steps over the line.

A cheap pulp  fantasy fiction for those whose only experience of a dramatic work is probably the last role playing fantasy XBOX game they twiddled their thumbs over.
All the show's characters and plots can be found in Fantasy Screenwriting For Dummies 101, but the fanbois of the show carry on in breathless wonder as if somehow this is all fresh, new and never been done before.
It's kind of amusing-especially when they hysterically lash out because they can't cope with criticism of what amounts to a Dungeons & Dragons pantomime about people who never existed in a time that never happened.

They're like asking to be pirated. I don't know how they expect people who don't have HBO to watch the show. It's not fair that we should be excluded too. I would be more then happy to purchase this show, but not HBO, or even cable for that matter.
What's to say??? Absolutely brilliant, to bad other shows don't put the same effort into their storyline. Acting is believable, sets are realistic, the whole thing is just so believable.
Excellent
Don't watch the "Inside the Ep" is you don't want spoilers. The creators geek out and always give a little too much away.

When I first saw Game of Thrones, I knew this season would be (based on how the series was being paced) the acid test. Corresponding to the first half of book 3, A Storm of Swords, this season would have moments that could make or break the show. Thankfully, the cast and crew proved to be more than up to the challenge and have continued to do so.

I'll refrain from mentioning a certain episode (you know the one) to avoid spoilers, but I will note that this season features the introduction of some of my favorite supporting characters: Meera Reed, Thoros of Myr, Tormund Giantsbane, and Beric Dondarrion. We also see Tywin Lannister in a larger role, and Charles Dance absolutely shines in the role. His withering put-downs bookend the season and are always a joy to watch.
Great series!
